headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Today's date is February 16, 2016, and this call is being recorded. The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, i
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Conference Call. Today's date is February 16, 2016, and this call is being recorded. 
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating and capital expenses, product development, new markets or prospects from the company's solutions and services and plans and expectations related to the Health Services business and other client achievements.
Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K, together with the company's other filings. A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted on the Investors section of cerner.com. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vince. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to the call. I will lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with result highlights and marketplace observations. And then Jeff Townsend, EVP and Chief of St
componenttext:
Thank you, Vince. Good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to the call. I will lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with result highlights and marketplace observations. And then Jeff Townsend, EVP and Chief of Staff, will provide an update on Intermountain Healthcare and Cerner's innovation. 
Now I will turn to our results. Q4 was a good finish to the year. Revenue, earnings and cash flow were all at or above targeted levels. Bookings were slightly below our guided levels, primarily because we didn't have a work steel on the quarter, but full year bookings were very strong. 
Our bookings revenue in Q4 was $1.35 billion, which reflects 16% growth over Q4 of '14. While that is a healthy growth rate, it is below our guided range. There was an IT work steel and a large professional services contract in our forecast that would have led us to comfortably achieving our guidance range. While they didn't close in Q4, we do expect it in future quarters. 
For the full year, our bookings revenue was $5.43 billion, which is 28% growth over 2014 and reflects more than $200 million of upside to the bookings guidance we provided throughout the year, including Q4.
Our revenue backlog ended the year at $14.2 billion, which is up from $10.6 billion a year ago. Revenue in the quarter was $1.18 billion, which is up 27% over Q4 of '14, in the middle of our guidance range.
The revenue composition for Q4 was $382 million in system sales, $247 million in support and maintenance, $528 million in services and $18 million in reimbursed travel.
Revenue in the quarter includes approximately $245 million from Health Services. This is down from approximately $250 million in Q3, but note that the deferred revenue adjustment was higher in Q4, so Health Services revenue was basically flat sequentially on an operational basis, which is in line with our expectations.
For the full year, revenue grew 30% over 2014 to $4.4 billion and includes approximately $930 million from Health Services. System sales revenue reflects a 36% increase over Q4 of, '1 with, the growth mainly driven by increase in subscriptions, which is where the addition of Health Services has had the biggest impact, as well as strong growth in licensed software. For the full year, system sales revenue grew by 36% over 2014. 
Our system sales margin percent in Q4 was 68.4%, which is up from 67.5% in Q3, due to strong sequential growth in licensed software. Full year system sales margin percent was 66.4%, which is basically flat compared to 2014. 
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 23% compared to Q4 of '14. Full year services revenue was up 28% over 2014.
Support and maintenance revenue increased 25% over Q4 of '14 and 35% for the full year, with a lower growth in Q4 due to the extra week in Q4 of 2014. 
Looking at revenue by geographic segment. Domestic revenue increased 28% over the year ago quarter $1.04 billion, and global revenue grew 21% at $234 million, both driven largely by the addition of Health Services. For the full year, domestic revenue grew 29%, and global grew 37%. 
As a preview to the annual update of our detailed business model that we will provide at our Investment Community Meeting on March 2 at HIMSS, I'd like to provide you with the total revenue and growth by business model for the full year 2015. 
Licensed software grew 24% to $564 million. Tech resale grew 21% to $330 million. Subscription increased 76% to $388 million. Professional services grew 13% to $1.24 billion. Managed services increased 56% to $858 million. Support and maintenance was up 35% to $976 million. And reimbursed travel was $73 million, which is down 19%.
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q4 was 83.0%, which is up from 81.3% in Q4 of '14, reflecting strong licensed software growth. Full year gross margin of 83% was up from 82.2% in 2014. 
Looking at operating spending. Our fourth quarter non-GAAP operating expenses, which exclude share-based compensation expense, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments, were $686 million, which is up 31% compared to adjusted Q4 of '14 operating expenses. This growth was primarily driven by the addition of the Health Services business. 
For the full year, operating expenses before share-based compensation expense, voluntary separation plan expense and acquisition-related adjustments were up  33% to $2.6 billion. 
The total year-over-year growth for each expense category in Q4 on a non-GAAP basis was: 26% for sales and client service, 33% for software development and 59% from D&A. Amortization of acquisition-related intangibles, the new line we added in Q2, was basically flat. 
For the full year, sales declined and service grew 29%, software development grew 38% and G&A grew 54%.
Moving to operating earnings and operating margins. Operating margin before share-based compensation expense, voluntary separation expense and acquisition-related adjustments was 24.7% in Q4, which is flat to the year ago period and up 20 basis points from Q3 of '15. Full year operating margin came in at 24.3%, which is basically flat compared to last year.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q4 were $166 million or $0.48 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $2.2 million, and adjusted EPS -- diluted EPS was $0.61, which is up 30% compared to Q4 of '14. Adjusted net earnings exclude share-based compensation expense, which had a net impact on GAAP earnings of $13 million or $0.04 per diluted share, as well as the voluntary separation plan expense, which had a net impact on GAAP earnings of $861,000 or less than $0.01 per diluted share. 
Adjusted net earnings also reflect adjustments related to the acquisition of Health Services, including Health Services acquisition-related amortization, which reduced GAAP net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $15 million and $0.04, respectively; other acquisition-related adjustments, which reduced GAAP net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $4 million and $0.01, respectively; and acquisition-related deferred revenue adjustment, which is not included in GAAP net earnings, but decreased -- increased adjusted net earnings and diluted earnings per share by $13 million and $0.04, respectively. 
For the full year, adjusted net earnings were $741 million and adjusted EPS was $2.11, which is  up 28% from 2014. 
Q4 tax rate for adjusted net earnings was 27%, which is lower than the normal range, primarily due to the R&D tax credit being reinstated in Q4. The R&D tax credit benefited EPS by approximately $0.04 or about $0.03 related to the first 3 quarters before the reinstatement of the credit. Therefore, we view our normalized adjusted EPS for the quarter as $0.58 instead of $0.61.
Now let's move to our balance sheet. [indiscernible] Q4 was $686 million of total cash and investments, which is down from $766 million in Q3, primarily due to the use of cash for our stock repurchase program. During the quarter, we finished the remaining $145 million of stock repurchases authorized in September this year, repurchasing 2.5 million shares at an average price of $58.40. For the year, we repurchased 5.7 million shares for $345 million or an average price of $60.39.
Moving to debt. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations, is $605 million, which is down slightly compared to Q3. Total receivables ended the quarter at $1.03 billion, which is down $19 million from Q3. Our Q4 DSO was 80 days, which is an improvement of 5 days compared to Q3. We are targeting DSO in the 70s in 2016. 
Operating cash flow for the quarter was extremely strong at $353 million, up from $272 million in Q3. Q4 capital expenditures was $107 million, and capitalized software was $60 million. Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures and capitalized software, was $186 million for the quarter, driven by strong operating cash flow. 
For the full year, operating cash flow was $948 million and free cash flow was $321 million, with capital expenditures of $362 million and capitalized software of $265 million.
As previously indicated, we expect capital expenditures to increase in 2016, primarily due to construction of the new campus. We still expect to generate solid free cash flow, with growth in operating cash flow offsetting most of the increase in capital expenditures. 
Now let's go to Q1 and full year 2016 guidance.
For Q1, we expect revenue between $1.15 billion and $1.2 billion, with the midpoint reflecting growth of 18% over Q1 of '15. For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.9 billion and $5.1 billion, reflecting 13% growth over 2015 at the midpoint. We expect Q1 adjusted EPS before share-based compensation and acquisition-related adjustments to be $0.52 to $0.54 per share, with the midpoint reflecting 18% growth over Q1 '15 adjusted EPS.
For the full year, we continue to expect adjusted EPS before share-based compensation and acquisition-related adjustments to be $2.30 to $2.40, as initially stated on our Q3 earnings call, with the midpoint reflecting 11% growth over 2015.
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings guidance in Q1 of $1.15 billion to $1.25 billion. The midpoint of this range is flat to Q1 of '15 bookings. Given a very tough comparable establishing Q1 of last year with 32% bookings growth and 28% growth for the full year in 2015, there will be some quarters this year with flat or low growth. We do expect for the year -- we do expect growth for the year, but note that even flat bookings will lead to a 2-year CAGR or 13%, also given that nearly 80% of our guided revenue is scheduled to come out of backlog. We believe we can deliver our revenue and earnings guidance even if bookings were flat. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Starting with number bookings. Our bookings revenue in Q4 of $1.35 billion reflects 16% growth over Q4 2014. As Marc mentioned, this
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. 
Starting with number bookings. Our bookings revenue in Q4 of $1.35 billion reflects 16% growth over Q4 2014. As Marc mentioned, this is slightly lower than expected, primarily due to less long-term bookings but still a strong level bookings contribute to our excellent growth for the year at 28%.
Bookings this quarter included another all-time high level of large contracts, with 46 contracts over $5 million, including 29 over $10 million. For the year, we had 153 contracts over $5 million, with 102 being over $10 million. This reflects 37% growth in contracts over $5 million and 62% growth in contracts over $10 million. 
For long-term bookings, we had a strong quarter for remote hosting, but we did not have a new ITWorks or RevWorks deal. So the percent of bookings from long-term contracts was 27%, which is about 7% lower than the average of the first 3 quarters. 
For the year, long-term bookings were 32% of the total bookings, which is 2% higher than last year, reflecting full-year strength in the work steals. 
We continued our new business momentum in Q4 with 36% of our bookings coming from outside our 4 million installed base. 2015 was, by far, the best year in our history from a new business standpoint. During the year, we signed more than double the number of new footprints that any year in our history, which we believe is evidence of our strong competitiveness and a large opportunity for competitive displacements. 
Our success was very broad during the year, with new business coming from IBM, regional hospitals, children's hospitals, community hospitals, state and federal, behavioral health, ambulatory surgery centers and physician groups. 
I believe 2015 was a breakthrough year from a competitive standpoint. I believe our success is driven by several factors.  First, we are much better in key areas to cover because of our R&D investments. In the past 5 years, we've invested more than $2 billion in R&D, with a focus on population health, positioning clinician experience, revenue cycles, consumer and comparability, open platforms and mobility. These investments are leading to much better performance in traditional competitions for EHR revenue cycle and further differentiation in areas like population health and open platform capabilities. 
We have also focused on predictable delivery capabilities, cost of ownership and delivering measurable value, which is critical in an environment where ROI is increasingly important.
Finally, the marketplace is becoming more aware of our primary competitor's higher cost of ownership, consistent openness and a lack of investment in cloud-based systems to support population health. We believe this is leading to more success against our primary competitor in EHR procurements and opportunities in their installed base for population health.
Turning to population health. 2015 was a great year. We had 30% bookings growth, and we now have 85 clients that have chosen the HealtheIntent platform to support their population health strategy. 
The highlight in 2015 was success outside of our EHR installed base, with one example being Geisinger Health System choosing HealtheIntent to extend their data-driven population health capabilities. This announcement made a clear statement to the market and has already added to our long list of opportunities outside of our EHR base. 
We currently have more than 20 opportunities outside our installed base, most of which use our primary competitor's EHR. I believe this activity is validating the broad opportunity for HealtheIntent and the shortcomings of our primary competitor. 
Another highlight was the that we were recently selected sport the health insights of the statewide Medicaid population. The state will use HealtheIntent's Enterprise Data Warehouse Solution to gain insights and intelligence from claims and clinical information across the state's Medicaid population, which will enable them to manage outcomes at an optimal level. This is a new market entry point for Cerner, and as additional example, our HealtheIntent expands Cerner reach beyond our EHR base. 
A key reason we're having so much success in selling HealtheIntent solutions is the clients who have already adopted them are getting great value and have become examples for the industry for how technology can enable and transition to quality and value-based reimbursement. A good example of this was captured in the January feature in Health data Management Magazine. Article covered Advocate Health Care success at using HealtheIntent platform together more than 60 different clinical and transactional data sources and use predictive algorithms to predict the risks, improve patient care and control costs. 
Moving to our revenue cycle business. We had a very good year with bookings that are more than double 2014 levels and included several of our large clients choosing Cerner for revenue cycle. 
Operationally, we brought 39 acute-care sites and 455 clinics live on Millennium revenue cycle. And we now have more than 1,800 live sites. Our momentum in revenue cycle of also reflected in very strong organic revenue growth, with revenue cycles nearly doubling in the past 3 years.
We expect continued strong growth going forward with many large clients forecasted the transition to Cerner, revenue cycle and a large volume of reports and extended business opportunities.
Moving to the ambulatory market, where we had a strong Q4 and year. For the year, ambulatory bookings grew over 50% and included 38 displacements of our primary ambulatory competitors. This included some of our largest acute-care clients choosing to replace their existing ambulatory supplier. We also had a strong start to penetrating the Health Services base with 16 Health Services clients choosing Cerner ambulatory. 
Our ambulatory business operating services offering also had a strong year and included 2 -- our 2 largest deals to date, both of which were displaced in a certain cloud competitor. 
We also had a strong year in the small hospital market with our cloud-based community works offering, where we ended the year with more than 130 clients. This year's success was driven by a combination of traditional new footprints, extensions through our health system clients and Healthcare Services migrations.
One highlight for the year was Great Plains health alliance selecting Cerner community works for their 25 critical access hospitals across Nebraska and Kansas. 
Looking ahead, the small hospital market remains very active and expect 2016 to be another good year. 
Now I'd like to provide an update on the Department of Defense project. I'm pleased with the work accomplished by the Leidos partnership for health events. Over the past several months, as we prepare for the pilot by rollout the next month has a partnership will have that many of the solutions that will be used in of limitation including some military-specific workflows, first responder application from aspect vaccination of your synchronization. Our collaborative effort has led to solution announcements and data portability essential to achieving the free flow of information across all the use of care and creating system that works for help their organizations are working to improve the well-being of individuals and communities. I believe this work can benefit the entire client base and the broader health care industry. 
Moving to Health Services. We had a good first year at signing Health Services clients to migrate to Millennium. Over the year, over 40 sites signed to migrate, including both IDNs and small hospitals. Operationally, I'm very pleased with how Cerner and Health Services teams have come together in the past year. Health Services associates have proven to be highly talented of adding value in many key areas of our business. 
Outside the U.S., we had a solid year. Full non-U.S. revenue growth was 37%, with most of this driven by the addition of Health Services, as organic revenue growth was [indiscernible] to low single digits due to the extra week in 2014, the impact of currency fluctuations and the lower activity in some markets where economies are struggling. Even though our non-U.S. results tend to be lumpier, we continue to believe in global markets represent a large opportunity for growth for both EHR and population health. And Cerner's well positioned for this opportunity with associates or offices more than 25 countries, a strong market position in many of them.
Now I'd would like to provide several marketplace observations. The first is that health systems are increasingly being asked to live in 2 worlds. A future state, driven by reimbursement model aligned to risk and quality outcomes and a current state where people you for services the predominant model. To bridge the gap between the present and the future, health systems need to solve the same problem; how to effectively manage and make disparate data meaningful and drive appropriate actions from it; solving current state problems such as proactively identifying reimbursement opportunities; driving efficiency across the venue-specific workflows; and true visibility into the quality of care we delivered a critical to enable health systems outperform their peers in an increasingly competitive health care market. 
To make the pivot, health systems will compete by proactively identifying populations at risk, redefining clinical engagement to preempt problems and enabling the persons to be a more active member of that carotene. We believe clients are looking for flat from to help bridge these worlds, compete more effectively and quality and efficiency in today's environment. And we're actively engaging to manage population in the future state. And HealtheIntent is a perfect fit for satisfying these needs. 
Second, the EHR placement remains very active. While regulatory pressures and solutions being sunset by competitors continue to have opportunities, we're also seeing more purchasing behavior driven b y value ambition, which is positive for Cerner.
Almost all EHR placement am also represent a revenue cycle opportunity, as providers prefer integrated clinical, ambulatory and revenue cycle systems. 
Third, consolidation in the hospital market has remained active, and this is creating opportunity for Cerner in the past 3 years, Cerner clients accounted for nearly 50% of the hospital buying activity creating an opportunity for more than 100 new footprints. Consolidation is not isolated in the provider market, with payers and HCIT suppliers also actively merging in the subject is still to compete in the evolving health care market. 
Fourth, we believe that EHR will involve from a transactional system to an intelligent activity-based system that will enable faster adoption of best practices, reduce variance, personalized care, improve outcomes and the ability to identify unit costs, which will be critical as reimbursement shifts to outcome-based and bottle payments.
This is consistent with the direction from has been headed as been a focus for efforts within our market healthcare. 
Finally, we believe openness and interoperability continue to become increasingly important. This benefits Cerner because our long-time commitment to interoperability and open system. This commitment was an advanced our knowledge of our Cerner Open Developer Experience, which is an open site designed to enhance collaboration with third-party and client developers with SMART on Fire applications. We believe this open platform has the potential to unlock future cutting-edge solutions that can benefit out only our client base, but the entire industry. 
In summary, there is a significant amount of change occurring in health care. Move the more change of the next 5 years than the last several decades, and Cerner is very well positioned to benefit from these changes. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Today, I'm going to provide an update of our collaboration with Intermountain Healthcare and what they refer to as I project and hos this is advancing Cerner's methodologies and our patient innovation. After completing the second regional d
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Today, I'm going to provide an update of our collaboration with Intermountain Healthcare and what they refer to as I project and hos this is advancing Cerner's methodologies and our patient innovation. 
After completing the second regional deployment in Q4 of 2015, we are now deploying an ever improving model system design across Intermountain in 2016, while continuing to innovate and improve in parallel. A component of how we're doing both at the same time will be a topic that Mark, the CIO at Intermountain, and I will be co-presenting at him in an education session titled what it takes for a success. Sharing our joint experiences and approaches to shift traditional information technology to improvement technology that will better align with Intermountain's journey to Learning Healthcare System. 
By applying the hybrid of agile development concepts with continuous quality improvement is to significantly change pace of both innovation and adoption. As a by-product of this work, the model is a method continue to shape Cerner's medical generation of continuous improvement methodologies, which are represented within our model system framework. 
The library of process models workflows, configuration and best practices are all part of a comprehensive kit that is applicable and measurable across our client base, dispute our life cycle from innovation to adoption at scale. 
If this foundation of techniques, tools and measurements are utilized across multiple organization, Cerner has continued to build on our ability to measure the experience of an end user as they navigate through our applications. The suite of analytics is called Cerner Advance, which includes a set of solutions that has leveraged our learning in the population health space. The difference is that this is the population of clinicians using the systems and the health status is how effectively they're utilizing the features and preferences of the system within their workflow. It also allows us to identify and personalize improvement interactions at the individual the user level, just like you would with care management for patients. We all learn a different pace and different ways. This technique applies an Amazon-like consumer profiling for clinicians, which we think is a key component of accelerating adoption. 
As I've shared before, our core component of our relationship with Intermountain has been the ability to advance innovation of clinical computing models more quickly. Within Cerner, we have started to use the term model practice to represent the focus on contextual, clinical decision-making within the workflow as a seamless by-product of patient care. 
In the case of Intermountain Healthcare, this is where their Care Process Models surface naturally. As Zane outlined, the evolution of reimbursement models is increasing to the demand to remove unnecessary variance in both cost and outcomes, which is shifting the focus to greater predictability and intelligence within the EMR experience.
We are now far enough along our journey together that we have represented a breath of structural care models for simple to complex and have extended the platform capabilities with a small set of Cerner clients to cover the continuum of care models, guidelines, pathways and predictive algorithms. The suite of clinical decisions support solutions is called Care Decisions. This covers a continuum of capabilities that can range from highly contextual point-in-time decisions like a patient with pneumonia presenting in the ED for treatment, to a series of massive pathways that will cover chronic conditions or diseases like cancer that could span several years.
Architecture of this platform is based on open principles allowing for both for the ability of predictive models that run from the cloud across multiple clinical data sets that span enterprises. This is something we call a SMART Zone, which is face up within the physician workflow and conceptual to the moment. 
Through this coordinated set of care decision capabilities that we think we can deliver intelligence that would create what Clayton Richardson refers to as the facilitated network in his book of, Innovators Prescription. We anticipate this configurator and collection of open systems will make up the model practice layer of our model efforts and enable clinical evidence to be shareable, portable and programmable across Cerner clients and the industry. 
Finally, I wanted to briefly share of a growing capability of advancing activity center design within the EMR. We have found that the ability to make measurements from application experiences, process variation, clinical evidence and outcomes provides significant new insights into our ability to achieve business and clinical objectives. This, too is becoming part of the evolution towards a Learning Healthcare System, with priorities being established based on desired outcomes versus implementation of technology. 
In many cases, this inverts the model that has most chaste in the air of Meaningful Use. What we found is that while independently, workflow may be followed, it may not be timely, which, in turn, impacts the effectiveness of adopting clinical evidence. This, in turn, produces a suboptimal outcome, even though several of the process inter- metrics may have indicated a good result. This concept is shaping the new understanding of critical thinking and how clinical integration defaults and an environment where everything is connected and instantaneously aware with the depth and breadth of data that is significantly larger. As the boundaries move from patient center visits to the continuous engagement of population health, there's no question that we'll acquire this next layer of intelligence in context. 
Our ability to predict and dynamically adopt the health care ecosystem based on activities and context is what we think drives the next tier of outcome improvement.
Before handing the call over to the questions, I wanted to provide a brief update on Neal. 
His initial treatments have gone well, and he is progressing as expected. He's very appreciative of all the well wishes and has received from associates, clients and investors and pleased with the accident year he's received. 
And Cerner coming of no doubt that his experience will further fuel his desire to continue to improve the system. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Jamie Stockton, Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Jamie Stockton, Wells Fargo.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: .First question, Marc. How much of the slowdown in bookings growth in 2016 is a result of long-term deals going down as a percentage of the overall bookings mix?
componenttext:
.
First question, Marc. How much of the slowdown in bookings growth in 2016 is a result of long-term deals going down as a percentage of the overall bookings mix?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind we're talking about Q1. And the long-term bookings do have various impacts on quarters. But the deals we talked about relative to not happened in Q4 are not slated to happen in Q1. So we're not going to get that -- those just really ove
componenttext: Well, keep in mind we're talking about Q1. And the long-term bookings do have various impacts on quarters. But the deals we talked about relative to not happened in Q4 are not slated to happen in Q1. So we're not going to get that -- those just really over quarter. They're going to probably happen in the first half of the year. So when we talk about Q1 bookings, it likely is going to be slightly lower, but it's not unusual for Q1 to be somewhat cyclical and a little bit lower than we've experienced. I think when we look at the first half of the year, when we see the pipeline that we have, I think we are very confident that we'll even growth in bookings. So Q1 is more a reflection of us exactly what we're seeing without any of the carryover deals from Q4 benefiting us.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look back to last 4, 5 years, and that kind of long-term component of bookings has been around 30%, is that a reasonable expectation for people to model out in 2016?
componenttext: When we look back to last 4, 5 years, and that kind of long-term component of bookings has been around 30%, is that a reasonable expectation for people to model out in 2016?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think '15 it was probably closer to 32 or 34%, so a little over 30%. I think, for the year, it was 32%. So you think if you say -- if you're using 30%, you're going to be within range. Our -- we've got opportunities for work steals. Some of
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think '15 it was probably closer to 32 or 34%, so a little over 30%. I think, for the year, it was 32%. So you think if you say -- if you're using 30%, you're going to be within range. Our -- we've got opportunities for work steals. Some of them -- a lot of the new deals come to us have a long-term component. So I think using 30% is pretty reasonable. Keep in mind, we don't expect for next year to have flat bookings, but our backlog currently will supply 79% of next year's revenue, just coming out of that backlog. So from an income statement perspective, we're well-suited even if bookings have been to be flat as we always indicate when we talk about our guidance. But we do see in the first half of the year, certainly as it gives us our best visibility, would expect to exceed and grow bookings for that period.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just one other question. I don't know if this is for you or Zane, but 2015 was a good year for Cerner as far as footprint expansion is concerned. You guys touched on that with your prepared remarks. If we set aside the DOD deal, because th
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just one other question. I don't know if this is for you or Zane, but 2015 was a good year for Cerner as far as footprint expansion is concerned. You guys touched on that with your prepared remarks. If we set aside the DOD deal, because that seems to be relatively onetime, and just look at the success that you had outside of that, can we expect 2016 to be as successful? Zane, I think you threw out a relatively large number for the number of facilities that you guys brought on the with incremental deals, somewhere in the kind of 1 70 [ph] range at an investor conference earlier this year. Is 2016 going to be a very similar year the way that you guys are seeing it play out? Or are we going to see it be a year where maybe there is a little bit of a slowdown and then 2017 reaccelerates?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would first start -- thanks for the first question. The DOD accounted for 8 sites for 2015. So in my account, it was -- we took the first work order, and that only represented 8 sites that we accounted for actually the 238 sites. So kind of updati
componenttext: Well, I would first start -- thanks for the first question. The DOD accounted for 8 sites for 2015. So in my account, it was -- we took the first work order, and that only represented 8 sites that we accounted for actually the 238 sites. So kind of updating where we have set up a previous conference that would have been through the third quarter. We're at 238 sites for the year, so that represented 8 of those 238. So very small percentage of those are related to the DOD in 2015. As we have successful moving forward with the DOD, we'd anticipate this additional insights coming into play. We see great market opportunity in 2016, similar to 2015 in terms of the opportunity that we see, particularly as we look out in the first 9 months of the year. And so I feel very strong about the opportunity and really our competitors from that. So I think we would expect to see similar numbers. It's hard to get it with each opportunity, number of sites is a little challenging because that can differ based on the mix that you have in there. But we see the same kind of levels of new market opportunities. So I think that kind of site-level performance will be pretty similar.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Cherny of Evercore ISI.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're coming up obviously on the 1 year anniversary of the Health Services acquisition actually profit P&L perspective. As you think about the business now versus where you're maybe a year ago or even when you announced the deal, can you maybe talk abo
componenttext: So we're coming up obviously on the 1 year anniversary of the Health Services acquisition actually profit P&L perspective. As you think about the business now versus where you're maybe a year ago or even when you announced the deal, can you maybe talk about the positives and negatives use relative to the Health Services business being onboarded and what that does on the go forward basis related to what you think that you run rate of this business and if you're an update that's an Analyst Day, I apologize for getting ahead of myself.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will be providing Health Services but I will give you some of that -- it's a great question. From a positive perspective, it's not what we set forth to do, which is bring on the client base that Health Services folks have, don't disrupt the growth of C
componenttext: We will be providing Health Services but I will give you some of that -- it's a great question. From a positive perspective, it's not what we set forth to do, which is bring on the client base that Health Services folks have, don't disrupt the growth of Cerner and the trajectory we're on and make sure that we retain the talent at Health Services, which were critically important elements. So I feel very good about those components. The number of migrations that we had, as I mentioned my prepared comments, was over 40. If you've looked at the previous 5 years combined, we had more conversions to Millennium than we had in the previous 5 years combined from just natural takeover, what happened from a migration perspective in the open-market place. So I would look at that as incredibly positive on the moving the traditional Siemens Health Services clients to a Millennium platform. The combination clients that have Cerner as a core EMR solution and as a revenue client, we have done a lot of work in terms of taking out the endpoints for those clients for managing those 2 different databases now that we're under one company and able to help those clients and really could de-risk that base from the revenue cycle perspective. So I feel really good about the overall performance of Health Services. And certainly, from a financial performance, we've met or exceeded our targets in terms of what we were attempted to accomplish from a bottom-line perspective.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc [indiscernible] up about anything of this [indiscernible] that might be slightly negative. Clearly, from our perspective, just being able to see the revenue line, their lack of a handle on the revenue number from their side and therefore, us
componenttext: This is Marc [indiscernible] up about anything of this [indiscernible] that might be slightly negative. Clearly, from our perspective, just being able to see the revenue line, their lack of a handle on the revenue number from their side and therefore, us having to kind of go through that in that impact if you talk about some of our revenue projections. Good news is that they have the same lack of visibility on spending, and that actually turned out to be better from a reduced spending standpoint than the lower revenue. So we all ended up a year actually. We had it there we want to be from in the we perspective, as Zane said. That's probably the thing iCentra will point out as the bid was a little bit lower than what I original expectations. But significantly better obviously impacted some of the guidance we provided. I think as far as the 2 companies coming together, that feels really good. I'm very impressed with both of our teams and the effort and time that they put in to achieving kind of one Cerner view of the world. I think, 1 year in, we just today updated our financial systems to PeopleSoft 9.1. And so we are already in the same financial systems, and all that is pretty impressive to get done within this 12-month period from date of close. So other than the revenue side, I'm pleased as well.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can sneak one more in. You guys talked a lot about the positive momentum. Obviously, I think, there's the dislocation between stockist both heading into today's as well as the aftermarket. Do you think any differently, given the cash flow generat
componenttext: And if I can sneak one more in. You guys talked a lot about the positive momentum. Obviously, I think, there's the dislocation between stockist both heading into today's as well as the aftermarket. Do you think any differently, given the cash flow generation of addressing the market, particularly to the advantage of the depressed valuation to a type of ASR? I know you completed the buyback. Any thoughts there would be greatly appreciated.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Certainly every year with our capital and we look to deploy it in the best possible manner. Certainly, stock repurchases are one of the things we've been doing with me. I don't know if people -- you guys track a lot of numbers for us. We probably kn
componenttext: Sure. Certainly every year with our capital and we look to deploy it in the best possible manner. Certainly, stock repurchases are one of the things we've been doing with me. I don't know if people -- you guys track a lot of numbers for us. We probably know what exactly. But the -- we've spent since 2013, '14 or '15, we've spent $731 million buying back about 13.3 million shares. So I think that certainly indicates that we're going to go-to-market of our normal philosophies is, obviously, as we discussed, purchasing shares to offset option dilution. I'm not sure if we would do an accelerated stock repurchase, but we might. Certainly, we have a board meeting in March, and I would expect the Board to be looking at this year and looking at our available cash that we'd like to dedicate toward repurchase and doing as they have every year, consider whether that's a good investment, which in the past, we certainly thought was a good investment. So we think the opportunities for the company are significant. We're going to be talking about our 10-year plan at our next board meeting. And I think, based on what we see there, and some of which we will actually share with you guys, I think that's -- it makes sense for us to consider that.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

Any other factor that impacting the current sales guidance?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: This is Marc. No, from a revenue perspective, our number has always been right around the $5 billion number. So clearly, a little -- in Q3, it was our preliminary view. This quarter, certainly more lockdown relative to our plan. And in our minds, it's basically unchanged.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then you mentioned the bookings were impacted by an ITWorks field that did not occur as well as, I think, you had mentioned on a project, which I didn't catch. But could you just elaborate on both? Because it sounded like ITWorks de
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then you mentioned the bookings were impacted by an ITWorks field that did not occur as well as, I think, you had mentioned on a project, which I didn't catch. But could you just elaborate on both? Because it sounded like ITWorks deal, you didn't expect it in 1Q, but you sounded very confident that it was to happen rather than if it would happen. So just trying to get a bit more clarity as to what was the delay and what gives you confidence that it'll indeed occur.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. We expect both because in the first half of the year, and so that is the statement. So it did not lose or go away, but absolutely, expect both those Tooker. The timing of the ITWorks opportunity in particular are somewhat -- can be somewhat
componenttext: This is Zane. We expect both because in the first half of the year, and so that is the statement. So it did not lose or go away, but absolutely, expect both those Tooker. The timing of the ITWorks opportunity in particular are somewhat -- can be somewhat tricky, and we actually entered the quarter with a couple of opportunities -- the fourth quarter with a couple opportunities to close. And neither of those came forward, but both of those are still in our pipeline, and we feel very bullish on closing those in 2016. These are big decisions that create lumpiness in our bookings because they tend to be very large numbers. And that's why when you track the -- we're 27% long-term bookings. And so that is reflected in the like ITWorks still reflected in that. Doesn't have a lot of near-term impact on the financials or outlook of the business. It's more of a longer-term aspect. So it's very normal with unfortunate, happy to be very large transactions and create some lumpiness in the model. That's why when we talk about first half of the year,  I feel very good about bookings growth in the first half of the year.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. Just a comment on ITWorks. Just keep in mind, we're rebalancing workforce. So it's not just doing transaction, it is actually being giving HR, trying to time, a variety of internal resources that they might have relative to that. So they are
componenttext: This is Marc. Just a comment on ITWorks. Just keep in mind, we're rebalancing workforce. So it's not just doing transaction, it is actually being giving HR, trying to time, a variety of internal resources that they might have relative to that. So they are, by their nature, lumpy. It's not something that we can push and make happen or not make happen. And sometimes, it's harder to predict exactly when it will happen.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: Sorry, Marc, the other piece I think, ultimate relationship. So you were playing for the long-term -- you're part of this organization business. We become one. And so it's not subject to the similar kinds of into the quarter, those types of elements. It's just one of those things where it will -- never find when the reporting every 91 days. We give our best view of that as we enter that period. But there's not going to be a lot of pushing on those kind of opportunities because it's the ultimate relationship play. And that is one of those things that we have to just have today with in terms of...

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: Just to clarify. It is a site like it's a competitive situation in terms of the reason why it'd go through. headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. These deals are typically noncompetitive. So what you're really attempting to do is help that organization move faster. And what they're doing from an IT perspective, create a known kind of expense stream to them, accelerate the capabilities of Cern
componenttext: Sure. These deals are typically noncompetitive. So what you're really attempting to do is help that organization move faster. And what they're doing from an IT perspective, create a known kind of expense stream to them, accelerate the capabilities of Cerner. There is a ton of work around, so they're not competitive scenarios. They really are -- and then, I would say, in both of these caves that we have here. It's not a win conversation. And both of those are moving forward. And I see those come through in 2016.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: I think you touched on a little bit, but around the milestone payments. I know, Mark, you talked about that being a little bit of an issue last quarter. The revenues came in line this quarter. Can you talk about sort of how you're performing those milestones. And maybe just to ask is as we think about going forward, how much of a factor you expect that to play in 2016?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I expect it to play a 0 factor. And we had none in Q4.
componenttext: I expect it to play a 0 factor. And we had none in Q4.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just secondly, really, you to talk obviously, you're not planning for 0 growth in bookings, but you can make the revenue numbers without it. Obviously, the big backlog here. Can that extent also beyond 2016? Or would you assume that we have
componenttext: Okay. And then just secondly, really, you to talk obviously, you're not planning for 0 growth in bookings, but you can make the revenue numbers without it. Obviously, the big backlog here. Can that extent also beyond 2016? Or would you assume that we have to have some -- a rebound in growth in bookings as we think further out?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you look at our history, it tends to be -- we have a strong bookings growth, and then the next year we have a strong revenue growth here. And if someone has figured out why that happens all the time, we're interested because it kind of som
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you look at our history, it tends to be -- we have a strong bookings growth, and then the next year we have a strong revenue growth here. And if someone has figured out why that happens all the time, we're interested because it kind of sometimes comes in cycles of that a little bit. Although when you grow the bookings over 30% in the year, growing the next years is going to be challenging on those tough comps, which we still believe we can grow. So I think from our standpoint, I think the backlog is strong, continues to grow. It's probably got, on average -- once you take out the initial component that supports 79% of our revenue next year, then you've got -- then basically probably point 3.5-year life of the remainder. So it will contribute significantly in 2017 absolutely from a backlog perspective. There's still plenty of medium firms elements of that backlog, particularly services, that roll out. And if we deliver the bookings that we expect certainly for this year, if we even just deliver flat bookings and don't grow bookings, we'll not only deliver '16, but we set ourselves up well for '17.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just for clarification. You said the 2-year stat was 13% of the growth. If we think about sort of normalize without Health Services last year, would you say we were doing better than that? Or any color around that.
componenttext: And just for clarification. You said the 2-year stat was 13% of the growth. If we think about sort of normalize without Health Services last year, would you say we were doing better than that? Or any color around that.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: 13% was the CAGR for 2 -- for basically for this year and Q1 guidance for next year. Keep in mind, the guidance for bookings is just for Q1, very targeted on what's in the, and we look forward to talking to you at the end of Q1 about Q2.
componenttext: 13% was the CAGR for 2 -- for basically for this year and Q1 guidance for next year. Keep in mind, the guidance for bookings is just for Q1, very targeted on what's in the, and we look forward to talking to you at the end of Q1 about Q2.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: Your next question is from George Hill of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first one is for Zane. And I guess, Zane, what iCentra want is kind of where do you feel like we are in the, I guess, in the demand environment ad the demand cycle? And I don't know if you saw there was a chart that got class how that there that showed
componenttext: My first one is for Zane. And I guess, Zane, what iCentra want is kind of where do you feel like we are in the, I guess, in the demand environment ad the demand cycle? And I don't know if you saw there was a chart that got class how that there that showed was 2016 was going to be a spike year for EMR replacement, and 2016 and 2017 were sharply down years. I'm trying to reconcile that come with kind of bookings shortfall expectations in Q4 and what would like an expectation for shortfall in Q1. And just are we at a point now where it's harder for Cerner to escape the gravity kind of the macro demand environment?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start with kind of the part of your assessment. Thanks for the question, George. From a new bookings perspective, new footprints were actually very strong in Q4. So 36% of our bookings. So we overachieved actually our internal projections and p
componenttext: Well, I'll start with kind of the part of your assessment. Thanks for the question, George. From a new bookings perspective, new footprints were actually very strong in Q4. So 36% of our bookings. So we overachieved actually our internal projections and plants around  the new business sites. So we saw very strong growth in 2015, what I would actually say was near 2011 kind of meaningful use era decision-making in 2015. And we expect that to continue into 2016. So our experience was really very strong opportunity in '15, 2016  and beyond. And from that perspective, we over attained. When you really look at though one piece that doesn't get down, it was really truly an ITWorks and professional services on a deal that did get back to close, the professional services with that opportunity did not close but will close. And so those aren't reflective of the marketplace. So I wouldn't look at the bookings element and say, "Any of that is reflective of marketplace." I'm looking for marketplace as hot as it's been for the past 5-plus years in that perspective. And our competitiveness all-time high, helps us to feel very good about our position as we move in forward. I think there is great opportunity in a number of this is where client can either sunset their solution or near track to do in upgrades to solution and platforms to prepare for future elements. And there's this lack of confidence in those companies and organizations' ability to invest and deliver contemporary solutions. So the level of buying opportunity in 2016 and '17 is very strong. And I think that will -- our view point right now is that there's a very strong marketplace, and over half of the marketplace is basically up for grabs. In addition to that, our success around the penetrating the non-Cerner EHR base with our population health solutions in our care word solution is very significant, represents there opportunity on the upside for us as we move forward. And I think that's another area where we'll need to continue to provide more information for use. You get to understand the impact of what that means for us because we'll see the market unfolding probably as -- I don't think I've ever seen it as robust as is today. And as I look forward, it looks incredibly robust. I just  think the makeup of that will involve in terms of both the March our decision as well as population health and other solutions that we have.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay that's helpful. Quick follow-up for Marc. We did talk about conversion revenue for a while and you talked about how 79% of the revenue for next year's going to come from the current backlog. Given the size of the backlog, can you talk about how many
componenttext: Okay that's helpful. Quick follow-up for Marc. We did talk about conversion revenue for a while and you talked about how 79% of the revenue for next year's going to come from the current backlog. Given the size of the backlog, can you talk about how many years of visibility to you feel like you have to that 79% of next year's revenue, which is, I guess, probably $4 billion? Should we think of the backlog is representing 3.5 years or 4 years of the number is of visibility? Like you've basically got 80% visibility to 4 years of revenue. Is that the right way of thinking about it?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think each year is going to be different, right? So the next year, as I look at '16, the 80% visibility that I have show up in the backlog. I've got long-term bookings with all the bookings success we've had. I'm still -- I've added in a lot of long
componenttext: No. I think each year is going to be different, right? So the next year, as I look at '16, the 80% visibility that I have show up in the backlog. I've got long-term bookings with all the bookings success we've had. I'm still -- I've added in a lot of long-term contracts. I mean, this year, we're 32% of our contracts are long term. So those aren't going to flow in to all significantly impact as a percent of the bookings number of those deals hit '17 or '18. So no, and we're, it's important. Deliver bookings to go see the backlog to drive the next year. But I can't tell you that I've got 80% of the next 4 years revenue sharing our backlog. That will be really nice thing to have happened. But the reality is the average life point you'd take out the '16 numbers is probably 3.5 average life. And you've got things that are 10 years in that and things that are shorter term. So from a visibility supervised outstanding visibility from a backlog, and especially from things that are in our bigger backlog, which includes support now, so I do have a significant visibility, but it's not -- wouldn't be 80%. Certainly, when I go into next year, I'm going to have delivered things from the $5.4-plus billion of bookings that I expect to deliver this year, that will then inform and help me on next year's numbers. So but certainly, I don't have a number that I can tell you write-off the top of my head of the percent of revenue and backlog today that will help '17. But certainly, it isn't 80% today, but by the time we get to the end of the year, my expectation is that keeps going up, which is impressive in the environment where I'm going to growth revenue double-digit next year.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Sean Dodge of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question is from Sean Dodge of Jefferies.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Zane, you touched on this briefly earlier, but on the over 40 Health Services sites that have committed to migrating, can you talk about maybe even quantified how the revenue profile of those clients are changing as they migrate? So how much extra Cerner-
componenttext: Zane, you touched on this briefly earlier, but on the over 40 Health Services sites that have committed to migrating, can you talk about maybe even quantified how the revenue profile of those clients are changing as they migrate? So how much extra Cerner-branded stuff have you been able to cross-sell into those sites as they migrate?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question. I would tell you that there is captive Health Services offerings, particularly around things like publishing health and ambulatory, even some more mundane things, if you will, around surgery and a full functioning ED solution. So as client
componenttext: Great question. I would tell you that there is captive Health Services offerings, particularly around things like publishing health and ambulatory, even some more mundane things, if you will, around surgery and a full functioning ED solution. So as clients come into -- do the migration, they will often procure additional software to fill out that solutions set, and that's what we've seen. And then we have additional implementation services to implement the new Millennium software. And then the recurring tends to stay fairly similar to what it has been. So the additional pops are in this -- the professional services and in the licensed software and any a related support fees that will go with those pieces, so for the long term. And the additional Cerner mode, most all of our clients do remote hosting. So they will come through or either do remote hosting aspects of that. And many of the Siemens Health Services clients were remote-hosted previously, but some of them were not. And so we see that trend picking up as well. So it's basically cookie cutter in terms of where the failure there's a percentage increase that we see because all clients are not created equal in terms of what they contracted for or what they want to do moving forward. But generally speaking, you see us rounding up a full solution set and doing the implementation, doing the hosting and ongoing maintenance. So it does represent an uplift and typically, overall revenues.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there has been a lucrative cross-sell. I think you have historically said that publishing health solutions currently comprise about 14% of revenue. What percentage of bookings would pop health be if you break it out that way?
componenttext: Okay. So there has been a lucrative cross-sell. I think you have historically said that publishing health solutions currently comprise about 14% of revenue. What percentage of bookings would pop health be if you break it out that way?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think pop health is 14% of revenues. I think we've talked about pop health, including various consulting elements of our in for quality improvement, et cetera, that the kind of move into the, about $450 million, so closer to 10%. So just to c
componenttext: Yes, I don't think pop health is 14% of revenues. I think we've talked about pop health, including various consulting elements of our in for quality improvement, et cetera, that the kind of move into the, about $450 million, so closer to 10%. So just to clarify.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Would the proportion of bookings be greater than that, though?
componenttext: Okay. Would the proportion of bookings be greater than that, though?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, not really. I mean, I think that given my the given the bucketing to service elements and other elements, a lot of the HealtheIntent style population health that we're selling today is kind of being acquired to our clients in small increments initia
componenttext: Well, not really. I mean, I think that given my the given the bucketing to service elements and other elements, a lot of the HealtheIntent style population health that we're selling today is kind of being acquired to our clients in small increments initially. So a lot of those, I don't know that they're pilots, but they're certainly smaller initial. I'm going to try this call I'm going to target a certain area that I want to use it in. And obviously, some of our time to not only working with publishing but they just won a work in a way to go back into their identify a population, where they could go actually do some proactive services for, which improves their revenue and also reduces the overall cost of whoever is taking over. So from a bookings standpoint, those have not been a significant contributor. So I'd say kind if you look at the total bookings, we gave be a percent of new clients, which most of which probably aren't having a significant component of HealtheIntent with a brand-new client. Our ITWorks client, works businesses, which are really not -- they're separated out. And when you look at the long-term being 30-plus percent if you look at the new clients 30-plus percent, you kind of got the bucket of things that are going in the base. So as a total of even HealtheIntent, even if it's 10% of that number, it's a smaller number relative to it.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Jeff Garro William Blair.
componenttext: Next question is from Jeff Garro William Blair.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Marc. It's some of that that's been talked about throughout 2015, but I wanted to ask now, after completing the full budget process, what's been learned about forecasting the professional services piece of revenue?
componenttext: Question for Marc. It's some of that that's been talked about throughout 2015, but I wanted to ask now, after completing the full budget process, what's been learned about forecasting the professional services piece of revenue?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think Q4 was a good indicator that the processes that we put in place and the additional scrutiny and reengineering of some of those processes, particularly on the services side, have been affected. I don't -- given that our additional view of our
componenttext: Well, I think Q4 was a good indicator that the processes that we put in place and the additional scrutiny and reengineering of some of those processes, particularly on the services side, have been affected. I don't -- given that our additional view of our revenue ended up, we delivered kind of exactly the midpoint of our guidance, which is I'm happy, obviously, about delivering the number that we guided to. So I think we've -- we certainly learned as we get bigger that you continue to scrutinize, you continue to look at the processes. Growth can mask processes that but might be effective as they should be. So that was a good wake-up call throughout our business that we need to make sure that we're diving deep into how we do things and make sure that we are not only doing them the most efficiency, but we're also doing it in a way to get the best answer. So I think I was very happy that Q4, from a revenue and income statement standpoint, was kind of spot on. So those processes that -- and the HS delivery was good as well. So those things have had the impact of us early in '15 feel like we're in a much better place now.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then just a quick follow-up. You guys have talked about some success selling the model system or model practice. And it sounds like that should translate into better visibility. But does it create some type of variation in the profession
componenttext: That's great. And then just a quick follow-up. You guys have talked about some success selling the model system or model practice. And it sounds like that should translate into better visibility. But does it create some type of variation in the professional services revenue stream that you might otherwise see from a more customized implementation?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, for the most part, we do [indiscernible] implementations. So for the most part, we got a bucket hours, and we are working against that bucket hours. And the revenue is that bucket of revenue, divided by how many hours you think you're going to go
componenttext: I think, for the most part, we do [indiscernible] implementations. So for the most part, we got a bucket hours, and we are working against that bucket hours. And the revenue is that bucket of revenue, divided by how many hours you think you're going to go hit, adjusted as you gain experience in that project. So the model -- what the model system should do is create a more predictable, not only a higher-quality project they'd better deliverable to the client, but more predictability. So to the extent that we have variances today and how long it takes to put in a system based on what we project, which is normally not too significant, the model system should make those even less. So from a revenue perspective, it should actually make our modeling better. And to the extent that we can use a model, to get it done faster, then obviously, that would help us on a fixed-fee contract from a margin perspective.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Richard Close of Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: Our next question is from Richard Close of Canaccord Genuity.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think were all trying to really figure out if we've hit the inflection point. Zane, it sounds from your commentary that you are pretty excited about the '16 and '17 from a new business opportunity. As we look like maybe beyond, as you think about 2, 3,
componenttext: I think were all trying to really figure out if we've hit the inflection point. Zane, it sounds from your commentary that you are pretty excited about the '16 and '17 from a new business opportunity. As we look like maybe beyond, as you think about 2, 3, 4 years out, where do you think the market is? I mean, do you think population health and ITWorks, maybe RevWorks, can step it up where you continue to show $5.5 billion in bookings or plus 2 to 3 years out?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We will lay out some of our plans at the HIMSS conference coming up, so I'll plug for Marc and Alan. So we'll actually lay it out as part of the HIMSS pieces. But I'm incredibly bullish about the marketplace and the need for health care technology an
componenttext: Yes. We will lay out some of our plans at the HIMSS conference coming up, so I'll plug for Marc and Alan. So we'll actually lay it out as part of the HIMSS pieces. But I'm incredibly bullish about the marketplace and the need for health care technology and the need for the solutions that we bring. Organizations need our scale to help them move faster. They have access to data no matter where the person is. And so the things that we do, both from a core EMR perspective as well as the population health, which, I think, long term, will drive more EHR growth back into all basis, in addition to the different works pieces, are absolutely needed by our clients. So the marketplace is very, very good. And in fact, 2015 was a great year. I look at '16 should be a very strong, strong year. It's very hard to look out in the 3- to 4-year range around the bookings numbers and say the exact bookings numbers. But we'll lay out exactly what we see in terms of those elements there. There's a strong need for more Healthcare IT and the services that we provide.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Marc. We've done okay in ITWorks. We're doing pretty well. We haven't got the 1 a quarter rhythm that I am kind of looking for. We really kind of pause on revenue cycle than the RevWorks deals with ICD-10. Those are all people, in our client
componenttext: Yes. This is Marc. We've done okay in ITWorks. We're doing pretty well. We haven't got the 1 a quarter rhythm that I am kind of looking for. We really kind of pause on revenue cycle than the RevWorks deals with ICD-10. Those are all people, in our client base, that are interested in those services. It is a little bit of matter of not if they're going to go to some third-party service provider for some of that, it's kind of when, and then we just need to be ready to be able to attack it and just hype that market. So I think the opportunities are out there but the good news is that except for the top 2 competitors in the environment, no one else is stepping up and saying, "We're really going to be great." I mean, in our marketplace, certainly, within the hospital marketplace, certainly, the people that have been our kind of not doing as well continue that trajectory. So there is the opportunity, as we've seen in '15, to go in and just place people competitors who had a footprint and have not delivered. And I think that continues. We got that continue through '16 and '17. So I don't -- I think it's difficult for us to tell you what our bookings are going to be in 4 years, but I think the elements or things that we will be selling will be big booking opportunities. So it wouldn't surprise me to keep at that level.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does the global market really have to ratchet up? Or is the commentary surrounding the U.S. market primarily?
componenttext: Does the global market really have to ratchet up? Or is the commentary surrounding the U.S. market primarily?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in the 3- to 4-year range, I think the U.S. market can drive a lot of the growth that we are looking for. I don't think we're reliant on any of the foreign markets to come up. I think that they'll continue as their economies start to recover, assu
componenttext: I think in the 3- to 4-year range, I think the U.S. market can drive a lot of the growth that we are looking for. I don't think we're reliant on any of the foreign markets to come up. I think that they'll continue as their economies start to recover, assuming they start to recover. They will -- there'll be a huge interest for them to do more with information technology. But I think until that happens, we don't need that to happen to drive kind of our 10-year growth view, which is of you that we got we'll share with you guys an updated version at HIMSS.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Greg Bolan of Avondale Partners.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Zane, I think you mentioned earlier kind of struck a cord, this idea of health systems kind of toggling between worlds, living and fee-for-service but obviously, dreaming or looking into the future on the ACO side. And I guess, does it feel like
componenttext: I guess, Zane, I think you mentioned earlier kind of struck a cord, this idea of health systems kind of toggling between worlds, living and fee-for-service but obviously, dreaming or looking into the future on the ACO side. And I guess, does it feel like that, that is going to create -- are you guys basically describing a situation where 2015 obviously was a good public -- good purchasing market just as a whole? You guys obviously gained share. It accentuated that growth rate in bookings. And in 2016, lot of confusion, lot of disruption coming. And this 2016's more of a market share gain year, and that's why there's a little bit of hesitancy in terms of -- I know you've just finished the year. You grew 28% bookings, but there's maybe a little bit more hesitancy as it relates to, hey, we think we can grow bookings on top of the 28% growth year. This is just more of, I guess, the evolution here as market share gain is kind of the focus on the kind of confusion that's out there in '16. Is that a fair assessment?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 16, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, here's how I'd look at it is the market -- what we talked about from the bookings perspective, was Q1 related only. So as we look at Q1 last year to Q1 of 2016, we're giving you our best guidance as it relates to that quarter. As it relates to the y
componenttext: Well, here's how I'd look at it is the market -- what we talked about from the bookings perspective, was Q1 related only. So as we look at Q1 last year to Q1 of 2016, we're giving you our best guidance as it relates to that quarter. As it relates to the year, I feel very strongly that we will see bookings growth for the year. We just turn out providing guidance as it relates to the year of bookings. There's great opportunities out there. In 2015, I see very similar around the new business opportunities that we had for 2015, I see the same dynamics at play for 2016. So there's still a competitors that are sunsetting solutions. There are competitors that have not kept contemporary architectures, and they don't age like a fine wine. And so those are born to become more and more at play in that. So I feel very good about the EHR market. In addition, there are all the works pieces of the business and the population health, which continues to get traction. So my expectation is that we will grow bookings in 2016 on a very tough comparable from 2015. We're just looking at Q1 and providing the best guidance that we can as we look at the mix of the opportunities in there. And so the sway of kind of one services piece and one ITWorks deal really shouldn't taint how we feel about the market and does not. So my long-term view of the marketplace and, frankly, short-term view is very, very bullish. And I feel really good about that. And because there has never been a bigger need for health care IT solutions. And so kind of that piece of living in a fee-for-service world and an at-risk model, it's coming slower. But the nice part is you can utilize our population health and solutions to maximize both worlds. And really, we're the only ones doing that, which is really unique, and it's creating a differentiation for us in the marketplace. And that's where, I think, as people begin to understand that, you'll see even accelerated growth on top of the great growth we've seen in that space.
