headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, maybe a quick one on the tech resale. In the last few years, we have seen a decline in the mix of tech resale revenues as overall revenue. If you look at your internal models, how much are you still baking in for 2016?
componenttext: Marc, maybe a quick one on the tech resale. In the last few years, we have seen a decline in the mix of tech resale revenues as overall revenue. If you look at your internal models, how much are you still baking in for 2016?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Revenue from basically tech resale, which is primarily hardware and also the resale of other third-party software? I mean, relative to our total number, it's -- I mean, 5%, 6% of revenue. It's a fairly small number. I think if you look at our slides that
componenttext: Revenue from basically tech resale, which is primarily hardware and also the resale of other third-party software? I mean, relative to our total number, it's -- I mean, 5%, 6% of revenue. It's a fairly small number. I think if you look at our slides that we provided at HIMSS, tech resale was probably $330 million in total. So I think if -- that gives you a sense. We don't expect that to grow. But in our world, that $330 million is just ripe for the taking, because we have those client relationships. We know who to go to. And we know when they're looking to go acquire that. Well, we don't make a whole lot money on the hardware, so [indiscernible] yet. That one doesn't hit the revenue. It doesn't really have much of a bottom-line impact. Selling that -- the solutions and third-party software is -- has more margin. So the reality is in this quarter when we were actually below tech resale revenue, we hit our margin number because of the margin we were driving out the third-party software and the higher margins that comes with it. So -- but it's not a growing part of our business, but we expect it to kind of continue to drive out at least that kind of level of revenue. And since it's, for us, the dollars that we get from the people that work on that, that small team are probably the highest dollars we drive that of any associate in the company. So it's worth the effort that we spend on it. It's not going to be a material driver of the business. And that's one of the reasons why being short that number in Q1 is not very concerning to me.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fair enough. And maybe, Zane, for you, on the small hospital. You said you saw a record number of deals in Q1. What's really happening in that marketplace? I thought there was slowdown in the market in the last year, 1.5 years, now it seems t
componenttext: Okay. That's fair enough. And maybe, Zane, for you, on the small hospital. You said you saw a record number of deals in Q1. What's really happening in that marketplace? I thought there was slowdown in the market in the last year, 1.5 years, now it seems to be even -- that market seems to be picking up -- back up again?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our experience has been that market has been very, very strong for the past couple of years and continues to. Our outlook for that is very good. So the activity levels are very high. And -- so there is a few things going on there. It all comes back to all
componenttext: Our experience has been that market has been very, very strong for the past couple of years and continues to. Our outlook for that is very good. So the activity levels are very high. And -- so there is a few things going on there. It all comes back to all health care, no matter if it's big or small, deserves a highly robust clinical foundational system by which to do business. And so those smaller organizations need very robust systems to operate in this environment. They need the same types of systems that the largest organizations need. And what you're seeing there is the lack of capabilities by some of those smaller providers to provide that type of deep clinical skills and functionality. So that -- I -- as we look forward, we continue to see that being a very good market. It was obviously a record for our CommunityWorks business. And as we look through the rest of the year, we anticipate it to be very, very strong.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: All right. You don't do revenue cycle in that market yet?

componenttext: Okay. Got it.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the strengths for us in that market is we offer a heck of a solution and capabilities because of our CommunityWorks approach to hosting the technology that allows those level of institutions to be able to afford. When you compare us to what the oth
componenttext: One of the strengths for us in that market is we offer a heck of a solution and capabilities because of our CommunityWorks approach to hosting the technology that allows those level of institutions to be able to afford. When you compare us to what the other people that are in that marketplace for the most part, we are so much better on the technology side. I think that helps drive our success.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: So you talked about a higher attachment rate of revenue cycle, pop health and ambulatory. Can you give us a sense of how much of a lift you get on a deal size relative to a stand-alone clinicals deal when you do those attachments?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: The -- we talked about the attachment principally around the Health Services side, but you're absolutely right, the attachment belongs also in the new business side for ambulatory and pop health and rev cycle. You'll see a percent -- particularly if there is ambulatory involved, you're talking about a 30% uplift when you see the full spectrum of those, often what happens in the initial new business activities is that the population health is kind of a small starter kit. So it will allow us to build upon that over the long run.

componenttextpreview: They were not. Our expectation coming in -- I think maybe some of our conversation was that we had one deal that it will happen later in the quarter. We had a partial component of another one that did hit Q1, but not at the size that was originally contem
componenttext: They were not. Our expectation coming in -- I think maybe some of our conversation was that we had one deal that it will happen later in the quarter. We had a partial component of another one that did hit Q1, but not at the size that was originally contemplated. We expect that to be more. And certainly, once again, no material ITWorks deals in the quarter.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the expected growth in the Works deals you said in the back half of the year, are those leaning towards RevWorks or ITWorks?
componenttext: Okay. And then the expected growth in the Works deals you said in the back half of the year, are those leaning towards RevWorks or ITWorks?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now ITWorks is the bigger population. As you recall, we had a slowdown on the RevWorks side relative to when the ICD-10 play out, focusing on Adventist and really working to make that a premier place to show our skills. So I think that, right now, I
componenttext: Right now ITWorks is the bigger population. As you recall, we had a slowdown on the RevWorks side relative to when the ICD-10 play out, focusing on Adventist and really working to make that a premier place to show our skills. So I think that, right now, ITWorks is primarily the thing that's showing up on the list. And I think it's even some of the stuff that Mike talk about relative just to our capabilities, our ability to do security, all the things that we experienced and have worked for here are things and skills outside of just running your health information platform that our clients are looking for. So they're looking to extend their capabilities by having us do that -- that activity.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jamie Stockton with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jamie Stockton with Wells Fargo.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a follow-up on what George was asking earlier on pop health. I think Mike said that you've got 6 core solutions that you're out there with today and there are 10 that are kind of on the horizon between now and the end of the decade. A couple of
componenttext: Maybe just a follow-up on what George was asking earlier on pop health. I think Mike said that you've got 6 core solutions that you're out there with today and there are 10 that are kind of on the horizon between now and the end of the decade. A couple of things. Could you talk about with the typical deal that you're signing today, how many of those 6 solutions are they taking upfront? And then maybe as a follow-up to that, is there something within those incremental 10 that you've got on the horizon that you're working on from a development standpoint where you say, "Man, once we get that out of the door, that will really be a positive catalyst for our effort in this area."

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. From a -- this is Zane. Typically, in a new business situation, there'll be 2 small, I will say, almost pilot-like population health elements. And we can grow with -- even in those 2 segments, because there'll be for a smaller portion of their popul
componenttext: Sure. From a -- this is Zane. Typically, in a new business situation, there'll be 2 small, I will say, almost pilot-like population health elements. And we can grow with -- even in those 2 segments, because there'll be for a smaller portion of their population. They may say, "Gosh, I've got a shared savings plan. I've got some -- I'm going to get something that I'm actually actively managing in population. It's a small population, I want to see that." But often it's things such as registries, so just kind of having the diabetic registries. So there'll be small elements, which gets the framework in place, which is really important for us, because it creates that framework upfront, which allows us to add on at a lower cost as we move forward and really scale out. And so often what you'll see is these kind of small pilot and small starters with 1 or 2 solutions and then growing forward. Our existing clients are taking more of the solutions that are generally available. But very similar to this, they're taking a more practical approach to whatever lives that they have at risk or conditions that they want to manage and creating a framework to grow that over time. So we can grow exponentially both within the platform -- within the solution set itself, because we'll add more population to that as well as we'll add more capabilities and functionality, which creates additional sales opportunities for us. And so, for me, it's -- I'm just anxious to really have an opportunity to provide that full-scale enterprise-wide solution set, which is our vision and what many of our clients are purchasing and really will take a lot of the noise out from some of these small niche pop health players that are out there.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. I think the -- if I was going to pick, care management is kind of something that I think is really critical. When we have a niche company making inroad into one of our clients, we've got -- we're out there with it, but we need to refine our
componenttext: This is Marc. I think the -- if I was going to pick, care management is kind of something that I think is really critical. When we have a niche company making inroad into one of our clients, we've got -- we're out there with it, but we need to refine our content, we need to improve that, we need to make that world-class. When we hit that, that, to me, is a little bit of a tipping point of -- that's really population health. And so I think you do that. You add to the registry, the data analytics, the warehouse capabilities that we've already delivered. We're already in a market out there. We have those solutions out there, but I think we're continuing to develop that to be able to be the lead -- a lead solution that really helps turn the tide on, improve -- increasing the population that this helps today. Because right now, as Zane said, it's usually a smaller population, which from a booking purpose means it's a smaller booking for us.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, if care management is one of the areas that you feel like is going to be a tipping point, is it just going to be in a technology-focused way? Or do you feel like the health systems are really looking for someone that they can lean on to also provide
componenttext: Marc, if care management is one of the areas that you feel like is going to be a tipping point, is it just going to be in a technology-focused way? Or do you feel like the health systems are really looking for someone that they can lean on to also provide that care manager on an outsourced basis?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. There is clearly large services opportunities associated with population health, and there is an opportunity to go provide additional services, similar to what we've done in other parts of our business to help clients scale. And I think the
componenttext: This is Zane. There is clearly large services opportunities associated with population health, and there is an opportunity to go provide additional services, similar to what we've done in other parts of our business to help clients scale. And I think the interesting part is I think there'll be -- I think many of us think of population health that some of these large organizations. I think you even think about some really smaller organizations. They can actually get their hands around that smaller population and really understand the full continuum of care and really can go after it in a different way. Those are going to be a lot of the clients that actually also need a lot of help with the services and the care management. So you absolutely point out a great point that that's going to be there.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Robert Jones with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually just wanted to stick with population health and I guess first say congrats on the Centra deal. I thought it was interesting that in the Centra announcement, it mentioned HealtheIntent would not only be used as the major pop health platform or too
componenttext: Actually just wanted to stick with population health and I guess first say congrats on the Centra deal. I thought it was interesting that in the Centra announcement, it mentioned HealtheIntent would not only be used as the major pop health platform or tool for the health system, but also for their health plan. I was wondering if may be you could just walk through specifically what you'll be providing on the health plan side? And then from a economic or business model standpoint, how does this deal compare to prior or other HealtheIntent contracts that you've signed?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Zane. I'm not going to comment on the specifics of the Centra of economics, but the Centra is a fine organization, and they have a number -- they have fully clinically integrated model in Central Virginia that has a health plan, and they are
componenttext: Well, this is Zane. I'm not going to comment on the specifics of the Centra of economics, but the Centra is a fine organization, and they have a number -- they have fully clinically integrated model in Central Virginia that has a health plan, and they are actively seeking -- taking on risk in their geography and they put a model together to do that. And what we're doing at the plan level is really helping them get access to all the data that they need no matter where it is. And they will take the full capabilities of HealtheIntent over time as we deliver them. So they're absolutely an organization that's bought into the vision of the enterprise-wide scale. And so we will deliver additional capabilities, which will help at both -- at not just the IDN level, but really at the plan level to help them manage that risk in a better way. And I think they are doing in a smart, intelligent way, which is swim towards the risk and take the first dollar coverage, and that's what we're helping them to do. And -- so they purchased what we have generally available but their commitment to us over the long-term is to rollout things as we release them.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Garen Sarafian with Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Garen Sarafian with Citigroup.

So was that solely due to the unpredictability in system sales and for no other reason? Did I understand that right?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, basically it's hardware. And the rest of our business, I was very comfortable with us being where we kind of projected and where people are -- where our range would have put -- landed at a midpoint. But given this quarter and given how those
componenttext: Yes. I mean, basically it's hardware. And the rest of our business, I was very comfortable with us being where we kind of projected and where people are -- where our range would have put -- landed at a midpoint. But given this quarter and given how those deals are now moving around a little bit from a timing perspective, I thought it was prudent to go ahead and lower the bottom end of the range for you to take into account hardware potential differences from our projections.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Useful. And then my follow-up is, back to UHS, which I felt was strategically a significant win. Some of the feedback that we received just from the communities is just seeing more data points on scale implementation of your Millennium rev cycle s
componenttext: Got it. Useful. And then my follow-up is, back to UHS, which I felt was strategically a significant win. Some of the feedback that we received just from the communities is just seeing more data points on scale implementation of your Millennium rev cycle solution. So I'm wondering, how long does it take for that -- for a large client for you to be able to sell that, sell this, or how this win sell other clients? And has it happened -- I think it was like about a month ago. So may be did this directly lead to additional sales you wouldn't have gotten otherwise or if there is any additional color there would be helpful?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. I think it's continued momentum -- positive momentum on the revenue cycle side. So we had a number of clients that have made a number of very large IDNs that have actually -- that have made a Cerner revenue cycle decision. I think you look a
componenttext: This is Zane. I think it's continued momentum -- positive momentum on the revenue cycle side. So we had a number of clients that have made a number of very large IDNs that have actually -- that have made a Cerner revenue cycle decision. I think you look at the UHS decision as -- especially on the investor-owned side that adds to the ISS footprint. I think you look forward to some other announcements in the investor-owned segment around revenue cycle. I think that's a strong statement about the -- how solid the solution set is. And so all of those help. And the ability to have those come online and be fully referenceable, it makes it even better. Intermountain has been very strong. Our work at Via Kristy [ph] has been very good. So those types of references have helped the revenue cycle side out. And the more that we add to that, the more it will lend itself to the credibility side of what we're doing around rev cycle. So all of those I view as incremental positive. I think it's a strong statement from the investor-owned side, the number of clients that are signing on.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. We kind of previewed coming into this quarter that we didn't expect to see ITWorks deals of any size, and that's what happened. So a lot of those long-term larger deals are what drives the long-term bookings and makes that kind of usually a
componenttext: This is Marc. We kind of previewed coming into this quarter that we didn't expect to see ITWorks deals of any size, and that's what happened. So a lot of those long-term larger deals are what drives the long-term bookings and makes that kind of usually a low 30s percent. When you compare that with the 37% we had in the year ago quarter, which was heavy on some of the long-term, it was -- you really kind of have a significant mixed difference. So that's the primary reason we don't -- didn't have those long-term bookings. When you take out the long-term component for the year ago quarter and this quarter, you actually saw about 18% growth in non-long-term bookings. So that's more reflective of kind of the overall business. We do expect those ITWorks deals to start hitting the bookings as we kind of move through the year. But Q1, we knew was going to be a little bit light and that's why we previewed our bookings wasn't going to -- was going to be relatively flat with our estimate, but that we would grow bookings obviously as we go through the year, which are Q2 to 10% growth that midpoint reflects.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when we talk about replacement opportunity, obviously, 36% of clients, new clients and that's -- we've been kind of like this -- kind of like trending up in the last few years. You talk about kind of like a pipeline right of $8 billion. But
componenttext: Okay. And then when we talk about replacement opportunity, obviously, 36% of clients, new clients and that's -- we've been kind of like this -- kind of like trending up in the last few years. You talk about kind of like a pipeline right of $8 billion. But what is the typical value of a replacement client? Because I'm assuming that the typical replacement client value now is broadly smaller than what it was kind of like as a greenfield 4 or 5 years ago. So can you just give us kind of like a sense of what goes into that $8 billion opportunity?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. So the $8 billion was specifically reflecting the pipeline we touched at HIMSS. Our pipeline is significantly larger than that. We don't disclose that number other than to say that it's continued to grow. So as we've harvested the pipeline,
componenttext: This is Zane. So the $8 billion was specifically reflecting the pipeline we touched at HIMSS. Our pipeline is significantly larger than that. We don't disclose that number other than to say that it's continued to grow. So as we've harvested the pipeline, we've actually continued to grow that pipeline. But the $8 billion is specific to the HIMSS element. The mix of business in there is highly dependent on the size of the organization that signs. And so -- which has been -- there has been a blend of that. There's -- the large regional players are very active in the market. The industry-owned segment has been very active. And so kind of across different segments. And I think you just have to look at the gross numbers given the pipeline is growing. It's -- the business activity is very, very strong.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think -- this is Marc. I think as you see the number of large deals we sign, those are good, continue to be -- have good numbers there. A replacement deal means they're going to buy everything. So that makes it a bigger deal. They're going to buy re
componenttext: And I think -- this is Marc. I think as you see the number of large deals we sign, those are good, continue to be -- have good numbers there. A replacement deal means they're going to buy everything. So that makes it a bigger deal. They're going to buy rev cycle, they're going to buy all the clinicals, they're going to buy probably lab, they're going to buy almost everything they got something of in their organization, whether it's from a single supplier or not, they're going to have to buy all of that. So these transactions actually tend to be pretty large relative to those organizations. So once again, very bite-size of the organization and users in a number of facilities, but -- that's why replacement market is very attractive for us.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- to date, most of them had been kind of pilots. So they might be 3 to 5 years in length. So it's, again, usually a single 1 or 2 of the solutions for a pilot period. So a little bit different than we expect the long-term approach to that to be. But
componenttext:
The -- to date, most of them had been kind of pilots. So they might be 3 to 5 years in length. So it's, again, usually a single 1 or 2 of the solutions for a pilot period. So a little bit different than we expect the long-term approach to that to be. But that's why they really haven't had an impact on our bookings today.
All right. Well, I want to thank everyone for being on the call. We see our Q1 results as a solid start to the year. Our pipeline continues to reflect significant market opportunity, and we are continuing to invest heavily in the innovation of solutions and services that will create future value for our clients. So with that, I bid you good day. Thanks so much.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is August 2, 2016, and this call is being recorded.The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, inclu
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is August 2, 2016, and this call is being recorded.
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating and capital expenses, product development, new markets or prospects for the company's solutions and services and plans and expectations related to the Health Services business and other client achievements.
Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filings.  A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in the earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted in the Investors section of cerner.com.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call.  I will lead off today with a review of the numbers; Neal Patterson, our President, we'll follow me with a results highlights and marketplace observations; and then Mike Nill, our Chief
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call.  I will lead off today with a review of the numbers; Neal Patterson, our President, we'll follow me with a results highlights and marketplace observations; and then Mike Nill, our Chief Operating Officer, will provide some additional highlights. 
Now I will turn to our results, which were solid across all key metrics. Our bookings revenue in Q2 is $1.4 billion, which reflects 9% growth over Q2 of '15. Note that this growth was driven on only 28% of bookings coming from long-term contracts in Q2 of '16 compared to 35% in the year ago quarter. 
Our revenue backlog ended the quarter at $15.0 billion, which is up 13% from $13.3 billion a year ago. Revenue in the quarter was $1.22 billion, which is up 8% over Q2 of '15 and in the middle of our guidance range. The revenue composition for Q2 is $333 million in system sales, $257 million in support and maintenance, $604 million in services and $22 million in reimbursed travel. 
System sales revenue for the quarter was up 6% compared to Q2 of '15 with strong growth in software being partially offset by a decline in hardware. While hardware did decline year-over-year against a tough comparable, it was up sequentially and in line with expected levels. 
Looking at systems sales margins, it was up 150 basis points over last year, reflecting strong software and lower hardware. 
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 12% compared to Q2 of '15. This is in line with our expectations and continues to reflect good execution via service organizations. Support and maintenance revenue increased 1% over Q2 of '15, reflecting the tough comparable. Support and maintenance is up 5% year-to-date, and we expect similar mid single-digit growth for the rest of the year. 
Looking at revenue by geographic segments, domestic revenue increased 8% over the year ago quarter to $1.073 billion and non-U.S. revenue grew 9% to $143 million. 
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q2 was 83.1%, which is up from 82.9% in Q2 of '15, reflecting strong software and services and lower hardware. Now I'll discuss spending and operating margin and net earnings. 
For these items, we provide both GAAP and adjusted or non-GAAP results. The adjusted results exclude share-based compensation expense, Health Services related to amortization, acquisition-related deferred revenue and other acquisition-related adjustments, which are detailed and reconciled to GAAP net earnings and our earnings release. 
Looking at operating spending, our second quarter GAAP operating expenses were $769 million compared to $762 million in the year ago period. Adjusted operating expenses were $721 million, which is up 9% compared to Q2 of '15. This growth was primarily driven by growth in personnel expense related to revenue-generating Associates. The total year-over-year change for each expense category in Q2 on an adjusted basis was 13% growth for sales and client service, 2% decline in software development, 6% growth for G&A and amortization of acquisition-related intangibles was down 12%.
Moving to operating margins. Our Q2 GAAP operating margin was 19.8% compared to 15.3% in the year-ago period. Our adjusted operating margin was 23.8% in Q2, which is down slightly from 24.2% in the year-ago period. This is in line with our previous indication that we expect margin expansion to be limited in 2016, but we do continue to believe we can expand margins 50 to 100 basis points annually after 2016.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q2 were $166 million or $0.48 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $199 million and adjusted diluted EPS was $0.58, which is up 12% compared to Q2 of '15. The Q2 tax rate was 32%, which is in line with our expected range of 32% to 33%. Now I'll move to our balance sheet. 
We ended Q2 with $720 million of total cash and investments, which is up slightly from $707 million in Q1 with most of our free cash flow being used to repurchase shares. During the quarter, we executed $50 million in stock repurchases, buying back 938,000 shares at an average price of $53.30. Year-to-date, we purchased 3.7 million shares at an average price of $53.41 for a total of $200 million out of the $300 million stock repurchase program authorized in March of this year.
Moving to debt. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations, is $585 million, which is down slightly compared to Q1. Total receivables ended the quarter at $983 million, which is up $42 million from Q1. Our Q2 DSO was 74 days, which is an improvement of 2 days compared to Q1 and 7 days better than a year ago.
operating cash flow for the quarter was $255 million, up from $109 million in Q2 of '15 and down from $327 million in Q1. The sequential decline is driven mostly by timing of tax payments and extra payroll in Q2. Year-to-date operating cash flow of $582 million reflects strong growth over $323 million of operating cash flow in the first half of last year.
Q2 capital expenditures were $118 million and capitalized software was $80 million. Free cash flow defined as operating cash flow, less capital purchases and capitalized software development cost, was $57 million for the quarter. This is up compared to negative free cash flow in Q2 of '15 and down from a very strong Q1 in '16, due to the lower operating cash flow and higher capital spending related to construction on our new campus. 
Year-to-date free cash flow of $209 million is in line with our expectations, and we expect solid free cash flow for the rest of the year even with spending on our campus remaining elevated. Next year, we expect a decline in capital expenditures resulting in a stronger free cash flow. Now I'll go through Q3 and full year 2016 guidance.
For Q3, we expect revenue between $1.2 billion and $1.275 billion with a mid-point reflecting growth of 10% over Q3 of '15. For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.9 billion and $5.0 billion. This range reflect the tightening of our previous range, mostly to capture the lower hardware revenue in the first half of the year, but still 12% full year growth at the mid-point. We expect Q3 diluted EPS to be $0.59 to $0.61 per share with the mid-point reflecting 11% growth over Q3 of '15.
For the full year, we continue to expect adjusted diluted EPS to be $2.30 to $2.40 with a mid-point reflecting 11% growth over 2015. Moving to bookings guidance, we expect bookings revenue in Q3 of $1.45 billion to $1.6 billion. The mid-point reflects a slight decline from Q3 '15, which was 44% higher than Q3 of '14, is by far the turn comparable period from last year.
The mid-point was still put year-to-date bookings above 2015, and we expect growth in Q4 as well. So we are still on track for our stated goal of 4 year growth of it was a very short 2015. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Our bookings were a record for Q2 and only second to our all-time high bookings of Q3 2015. As Marc indicated, our total bookings grew
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Our bookings were a record for Q2 and only second to our all-time high bookings of Q3 2015. As Marc indicated, our total bookings grew 9% despite lower contributions from long-term bookings than last year. The 28% of Q2 2016 bookings from long-term reflects contributions from both ITWorks and managed services, but were still below the elevated level of 35% in Q2 of 2015. The non long-term portion of Q2 2016 bookings grew 20%, reflecting strong levels of solution and services sales, both into our base and to new clients. Bookings this quarter included several large contracts with 45 contracts over $5 million, including 28 over $10 million.
34% of bookings this quarter came from outside our $4 million install base. This high level of new business is a result of an active replacement market, an ongoing success against our primary competitor. The keys to our success continued to be our improved solutions, delivery capabilities, lower cost of ownership, ability to deliver value and our population health and open platform capabilities. I believe that compared favorably to our primary competitor in all of these areas and this is reflected in our run rate. 
Overall, I believe Cerner is viewed as a safe just bank resolution needs, as well as best part to help clients achieve value from their investments and position of them for success as the market shares from a focus on care to a focus on health and wellness.
A good example to opportunity in the marketplace and our competitiveness was Covenant Health selecting Cerner, which we announced last week. Covenant health is 1,900 bed health system based in Eastern Tennessee with 10 hospitals and nearly 100 and with 20 [ph] facilities. They will be deploying Cerner Millennium EHR and clinically driven revenue type of solutions, as well as the HealtheIntent population health solutions across all venues of care. Cerner's integrated solutions across clinical and revenue cycle and acute and ambulatory, proven ability to deliver value and predictable cost and our population health care capabilities were important differentiators for us when competing for this business.
Looking ahead, we believe the replacement market will remain active, given the high number of hospitals on legacy platforms, many of which are being sunsetted. These opportunities reflecting our leading indicators with our new business pipeline and sales activity at all-time highs. 
Now I'll discuss revenue cycle. We had another great quarter, all new EHR clients included revenue cycles as part of their purchase, reflecting continued focus by the market on clinically driven revenue cycle. This preference is also reflected an ongoing success in our installed base with several more large clients choosing Cerner for acute revenue cycle and a military business office services. 
In addition to a very strong quarter, we also made a great addition to our executive team. As we announced in July, Jeff Hurst will be joining Cerner on September 1 as Senior Vice President of Cerner Revenues Stock of Management and President of Cerner RevWorks. This is a new position and the existing revenue cycle on RevWorks will report to Jeff. Jeff comes with us from Florida Hospital of 2,700 bed acute care medical facility and was a member of the Adventus health System, where he directed all financial and clinical revenue cycle functions and had a responsibility for key organizational strategies. He is respected industry thought leader and proven executive, and he brings an important provider perspective to Cerner.
As you know, we have made significant investments in revenue cycle that have led to very strong growth in recent years. Our hiring Jeff is an indication that we believe we are still in the early stages of a significant growth opportunity as we help our clients navigate the rapidly evolving reimbursement landscape and that we're investing in talent that will help us capitalize on opportunity and to contribute to the success of our clients.
Now I'll shift to discussing our population health business, where we had a great quarter. We added several new clients to the HealtheIntent platform, and we also expanded the scope of population health solutions at some of our largest existing clients. Our comprehensive approach to population health remains differentiated in the marketplace, and we continue to add solutions to the HealtheIntent platform. I believe will continue displaced numeration niche offerings because of the power of the platform and the ability to integrate with the EHR workflow. 
The volume clients that have purchased initial solutions and our HealtheIntent platform is impressive. We recently passed the 100 client milestone. We believe this positions us for a significant ramp in revenue in the coming years as these clients add more solutions and lives to the platform, which will increase the firm member per month rate number of members. We expect to driver of this to been growing shifts and reimbursement that are leading to more risk assumption by our clients. And we believe to shift away from traditional fee-for-service is gaining momentum. With the Medicare access and ship reutilization act or MACRA and the new merit based incentive payment systems, ramping and coming years as CMS continues to focus on value and quality payments.
Moving to the ample market, where we had record results with strengthened ambulatory EHR, practice management and business office services. Similar to recent quarters, our results include some of the largest acute care clients choosing Cerner's clinical and revenue cycle solutions for their ambulatory settings. 
We also had a strong quarter in the small hospital market. Our cloud based community works offering continues to be competitive at once small hospital vendors. A recent noteworthy win for community works was the displacement of a failed attempted go live by a cloud-based vendor that has been making a push in recent years to expand from ambulatory market to hospitals. We have several active opportunities displaced the same competitor in both ambulatory and small hospital settings, suggesting their approach is spending about 3x as much on sales and marketing as they do on research and development may not be the most effective approach for their clients.
Outside the U.S, despite some macroeconomic headwinds, we had a good quarter. Non-U.S. revenue grew 9% year-over-year with noteworthy areas of strength, including Australia, Germany and the Middle East. As Mike will discuss, the Middle East strength included CommunityWorks, which is a positive sign as it highlights a largely untapped global opportunity for ITWorks. 
In summary, I'd please with our execution in Q2 and believe we are well positioned to have a good second half for the year. With that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and Cerner's model experience initiative. I'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client, a large expansion within existing client and a very strong sale
componenttext:
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and Cerner's model experience initiative. I'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client, a large expansion within existing client and a very strong sales back into our client base. Regarding our new client, this quite is not only new to ITWorks, but they are in new EHR client as well. And the EHR win displaces our primary competitor. 
The client is a new Children's Hospital in Dubai, and we scheduled to implement our primary competitor solution, but concluded Cerner is a better choice to meet their needs. Our ability to work quickly in order to enable them to be ready for the hospital schedule opening date, as well as provide full IT services through ITWorks, were both the key factors in us being selected. In addition, the success we've had with another client in the region was a very helpful and illustrating the value of the ITWorks model, something our competitor does not offer.
Looking ahead, our pipeline for ITWorks is significant and include some very large clients. While the timing of ITWorks deals has been lumpy and will likely continue to be, we're confident that we remain a strong contributor to our growth. The value proposition to our clients is very appealing, especially in an environment where they have pressure on operating cost, limited access to IT talent and increasing pressure in light of the industry issues related to security.
Now I'd like to briefly discuss an initiative we call model experience. The model experience is an extension of the model system, which we have discussed in the past. The Model Experience represents a meaningful shift in our approach to implement our solutions, workflows and standards at our client sites. It presents all of Cerner's standards and content within a controlled environment, where the best practice from workflows and the latest capabilities are captured. NH client systems can be optimized based upon their specific needs. The model experience goes beyond just focusing on the EHR. It also provides clients optimal recommendations for leveraging HealtheIntent, Millennium and careware solutions.
In addition, model experience uses a continued investment approach for adopting recommendations, which ensures our clients will continuously will be able to maximize the value of our solutions.
In summary, I believe the model experience positions us well for our clients to achieve value from the existing environments and keep up with the rapidly evolving health care landscape. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Hey, I want to talk about the small hospital market. And clearly, you're indicating that you're having a lot of success here downstream in the market. Can you -- what are the characteristics that these smaller hospitals are looking for right now? And what do you think is right now really differentiating? Is it the ability to still retain control over how the workflow and how they practice delivering care? Or can you talk abut some of the characteristics when your discussions with them?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Charles. This is Zane. The characteristics are pretty straightforward. Health care is complex the matter how small the organization is. And so having the depth of a Millennium and Cerner full functioning system, our ability to deliver in a cloud-b
componenttext: Thanks, Charles. This is Zane. The characteristics are pretty straightforward. Health care is complex the matter how small the organization is. And so having the depth of a Millennium and Cerner full functioning system, our ability to deliver in a cloud-based environment, which allows us to have a lower total cost to ownership and a very fixed and predictable model, is very appealing because they need the full functional solutions sets to be -- able to be delivered in a cost-effective manner. And so those we're kind of the key criteria. Many of them are in a situation where they are forced to leave their legacy provider. And so they are looking for a replacement that takes them to a safe place, as well as put them in good standing from the long stead that connect to -- in the evolving marketplace for health care.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. And Marc, if I could talk about how that flows into the model. When you're sewing down to the hospital down cloud based kind of platform, is it a subscription model? componenttext: This is Zane. It is a typical hosting software license arrangement. Sometimes the models are, and it will include subscriptions as well. But as it relates to bookings, it's going to flow through our model the same way.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, in terms of the pacing of operating margin expansion throughout the year or what's contemplated in sort of the second half guidance. Can you just help us understand in the face of sort of what you did with revenue for the full year, how to th
componenttext: I'm curious, in terms of the pacing of operating margin expansion throughout the year or what's contemplated in sort of the second half guidance. Can you just help us understand in the face of sort of what you did with revenue for the full year, how to think about the other mechanics of that would get us to the upper end of the earnings range for the year?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Marc. I think the key thing relative to the revenue guidance was taking out kind of the hardware component or hardware that we've seen earlier in the year and then flowing that through the rest. And that's why we took the higher and off the r
componenttext: Yes, this is Marc. I think the key thing relative to the revenue guidance was taking out kind of the hardware component or hardware that we've seen earlier in the year and then flowing that through the rest. And that's why we took the higher and off the revenue. I think, as we roll forward, we still have a year where we expected our margins to be relatively flat year-over-year, and I think that's kind of what we're seeing and what we're delivering. I think that's still our expectations as we roll through. Obviously, to the extent that we increase our higher-margin elements of the business, software, et cetera, there's a chance to increase the operating margins. But I think, overall, given the mix we have, which feels like pretty good mix between services, software and the rest of our business, I don't know that we're going to have a big change in 2016 relative to margin expansion. I feel very good as we roll into '17 you'll start to see us get back on a track of 50 to 100 basis point of margin expansion that you've seen us historically been able to do. But that's, right now, our view as we look out in the second half of the year, given our guidance for Q3, I think would be relatively flat year-over-year as we continue to see basically low double-digit revenue growth.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: That's helpful. I guess, it seems like it implies a bit of improvement is because you've been down in the first part of this year, that does the second half had to have a little bit more expansion. But I guess, one other quick things. So on the international business, look like that improved sort of sequentially. Maybe a little bit more color where you're seeing some of the demand there? And then, I guess, how you're thinking about that pacing through the rest of the year because the comps. I think, eased a little bit there.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane, Ross. So as we mentioned in my comments, we saw strength in several areas, but heavily, the Middle East as reference and Mike's commentary around the ITWorks perspective and Germany as well, we saw good performance there. And I think the pie
componenttext: This is Zane, Ross. So as we mentioned in my comments, we saw strength in several areas, but heavily, the Middle East as reference and Mike's commentary around the ITWorks perspective and Germany as well, we saw good performance there. And I think the piece around the Middle East is very, very pleasing given of the price of oil in that marketplace. And really it's a proof point of really good work to that's been done by the teams in the Middle East as well as what some of that client had seen here by some of the ITWorks opportunities area that we've worked with in the U.S. So I think that model will continue to have -- quite good opportunities for us across the globe.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: This is Marc, I think we also kind of see some more traditional markets Australia, Canada, seeing some activity beginning to percolate in the U.K, which is a positive compared to kind of where they've been. So they want phase is not growing a lot more since post HS Germany's doing well. But overall, Europe is still an area we think should grow as the economies recover. So -- but we were certainly, pleased with the Middle East activity this quarter.

componenttext: So somewhat, you guys have been selling lots of revenue cycle software, but it's been a little while since we've been a RevWorks deal signed. headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Sure, this is Zane. the -- I think you hit the nail on had in terms of we've seen great market opportunity around the business office services propositions and then really, the extended business office services doing more services along those lines. The growth has been very good in both of those areas. As it relates to full outsourcing, we've really taken approach of digesting the clients that we have and really being focused on making sure that the next opportunity is a really good one for us. And we did the EBO services and the business services offices are good entrée into the future of those stockholder opportunities. So we still see full revenue cycle outsourcing as a good marketplace for us, but we think it will grow into those markets over time through this -- the business office service and the EBO, which have been very strong in demand.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, there's no anticipation that you're going to see our long-term bookings percentage do anything different as you did last year. We saw some mid 30s or higher percent from long-term this year. This year, we've been below 30%. I think 30% is probably our
componenttext: No, there's no anticipation that you're going to see our long-term bookings percentage do anything different as you did last year. We saw some mid 30s or higher percent from long-term this year. This year, we've been below 30%. I think 30% is probably our target. So I think that's where you're going to see going to the bookings. We don't anticipate any large spikes from any tools we've talked about before. Those deals are still out there, but I don't know if Q3 is a timing for either of those at this point.

componenttext: So as I think about the -- Marc, you've talked about setting up well for margin expansion in 2017. Could you maybe just walk us through kind of the variables, the stars that you'd kind of see aligning to set that -- set it up for margin expansion next year?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- for us, the key is continuing seeing the demand in the marketplace obviously, continuing to be able to sell software and sell the high margin elements of the business that we have been seeing. If hardware continues to be at the current
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- for us, the key is continuing seeing the demand in the marketplace obviously, continuing to be able to sell software and sell the high margin elements of the business that we have been seeing. If hardware continues to be at the current level once we get through, that's assuming we can continue to grow the margin as double-digit, which we expect to do, that should improve the overall margins. Historically, you've seen us leverage our spend. You've seen us beverage R&D, growth relative to revenue growth. And those are kind of the drivers that will kind of kick in that you've seen traditionally from -- for us that are driving some of that growth. I think even in our businesses, as we do the business model slight every year, you see slight increases in conservation margins from a share of those. So if you really just look at our size and the expense components, if you grow R&D's lower than revenue and you grow SG&A slower than revenue, it gives you 50 to 100 basis points. So really, as long as we do those 2 things, we should get back on track.

So I think certainly, they want to make sure that they're getting what they're paying for. Luckily, our petition and the ability to deliver is minimizing contractual requirements that we have that would impact the financials for the most part.

componenttext: Sure, this is Zane. It's actually coming mostly from the displacement of other competitors. componenttext: I guess, June, if we talk about the Health Services base, typically in M&A and a space you see it that so it's kind of a go forward decision-making process. headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- I don't -- George, I don't have the exact numbers handy in terms of as it relates to the exact numbers that have made a go-forward decision. So I have to provide that to you later. As it relates to the win rates, I can tell you that we modeled out
componenttext: The -- I don't -- George, I don't have the exact numbers handy in terms of as it relates to the exact numbers that have made a go-forward decision. So I have to provide that to you later. As it relates to the win rates, I can tell you that we modeled out as part of the acquisition where we anticipated those what our win rates would look like. And those had mirrored what our expectations had been almost exactly terms of where we thought we would end up in a smaller end of the spectrum to the large end of our spectrum. So our win rate has been actually quite high in the low end. And then in the larger upper end, it's been -- it still bit north of our traditional win rate.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Again, Marc, I guess, my fit well assessment of the retention has been in line with expectations, but we know that there's been some churn. I guess. Can you talk me through the synergy delivery and have the synergies on the deal thus far been delive
componenttext: Okay. Again, Marc, I guess, my fit well assessment of the retention has been in line with expectations, but we know that there's been some churn. I guess. Can you talk me through the synergy delivery and have the synergies on the deal thus far been delivered? Or have some of the churn in the client base eaten away at some of the synergy opportunity? And I guess, just trying to think about returns on the deal and whether or not the deal is measuring up to expectations.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Keep in mind, certainly, when we bought them and closed, they already a small group of clients that have decided and notified Siemens that they were leading the fold. Every one of those is still writing me their monthly check or others made their mo
componenttext: Sure. Keep in mind, certainly, when we bought them and closed, they already a small group of clients that have decided and notified Siemens that they were leading the fold. Every one of those is still writing me their monthly check or others made their monthly check for their contract duration, which can extend from anywhere from 3 to 5 more years. So the impact of a client's making decision to leave actually tails off -- has a very long tail to it. So from our business small perspective and certainly, in the near-term that we've been working through, the synergies primarily as we talked about were costs related. And I think we've done a very good job of delivering on those cost synergies. So I think, overall, if you look at the, kind of the bottom line of HS, we are ahead relative to an OE, slightly ahead of where we would have modeled ourselves. I think we're slightly ahead of where we would have expected from a retention standpoint. So today, we're actually very pleased with how it's modeling out and how these clients are starting to really get into the Cerner mode and see us as their provider moving their allegiance over from the HS book. So today, things are working very well.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: No, there are no change in how we bill or how we sign contracts relative to support maintenance. The HS acquisition obviously came in, bought a big ball this of support dollars there. They came in Q2 of year ago. Those dollars were a little bit higher. They were a little bit lower in Q3 and then kind of evened out as we move forward. So that's -- when you look at this quarter, there's a little bit of a lower percent increase. But based on the side and a large, large numbers and basically we continue to turn on projects is our normal pace. You kind of go look as that number gets large somewhere in the mid-single digits growth on that line.

componenttext: Okay. Then maybe just as far as the guidance is concerned. If I kind of take what you've done year-to-date and I back out what your guidance is for 3Q, there's a decent step-up in the fourth quarter to get to the mid-point of the annual revenue guidance. Is there anything notable that would be occurring in the fourth quarter that would get us to that number like an unusually strong hardware quarter, anything like that, that we should be keeping in mind?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- there's nothing from a hardware perspective. We -- I am passed the time when I am counting on our to deliver anything from my top line. So no, that's just the strength of business. A little bit of Q4 impact. We are getting into a time when
componenttext: No, I don't -- there's nothing from a hardware perspective. We -- I am passed the time when I am counting on our to deliver anything from my top line. So no, that's just the strength of business. A little bit of Q4 impact. We are getting into a time when you're seeing a little more of the cyclical nature of the business, where we always had traditional strong Q4. I think, as we look at the backlog, as we do all the analysis that we do from our forecast meetings and forecast, not only the next quarter, but obviously, 3 more quarters out, Q4 is just lined up to be a good solid quarter with nothing unique driving that revenue increase. It's just the business and driving the revenue out of the backlog.

componenttext: Well, I think, as we look at Q4, the -- some of the seasonality we see on the income side, you'll see it. It's just against the comp that went up 44% in the year ago quarter. So I think we're -- once again, we don't talk about bookings outside of the oncoming quarter. But we are very comfortable that for the full year, we would expect to grow bookings. And so, obviously, to do that, we'd expect to have a pretty decent Q4.

componenttext: Yes, so Marc is referring to our installed base overall, which -- but most -- I think what you've seen over the last couple of year has been integrated revenue cycle, clinical revenue cycle decision, and that number has continued to inch up where this quarter was 100% of them selecting revenue cycle as part of that. And the -- from an implementation perspective, we are into thousands of ammo to our providers. We're into the hundreds of Cerner Millennium sites. So lots of scale across different sizes of organizations. So from small to extremely large organizations running Cerner revenue cycle across that and that's helped with a credibility and the solution side as we move forward. As it relates to individual projects, those really come down to the individual client situation themselves. Many are big bang model. And so I would say half of those are big bang. And I would say the other half, they have some phased approach based on what their risk tolerance is, what the sunset solutions are that they're facing and what the key criteria that they're looking at operationally to solve. So those come down to individual client base decision.
