headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is August 2, 2016, and this call is being recorded.The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, inclu
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is August 2, 2016, and this call is being recorded.
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating and capital expenses, product development, new markets or prospects for the company's solutions and services and plans and expectations related to the Health Services business and other client's achievements.
Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filings.  A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in the earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted in the Investors Section of cerner.com.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call.  I will lead off today with a review of the numbers; Zane Burke, our President, we'll follow me with a results highlights and marketplace observations; and then Mike Nill, our Chief Ope
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call.  I will lead off today with a review of the numbers; Zane Burke, our President, we'll follow me with a results highlights and marketplace observations; and then Mike Nill, our Chief Operating Officer will provide some additional highlights. 
Now I will turn to our results, which were solid across all key metrics. Our bookings revenue in Q2 is $1.4 billion, which reflects 9% growth over Q2 of '15. Note that this growth was driven on only 28% of bookings coming from long-term contracts in Q2 of '16 compared to 35% in the year ago quarter. 
Our revenue backlog ended the quarter at $15.0 billion, which is up 13% from $13.3 billion a year ago. Revenue in the quarter was $1.22 billion, which is up 8% over Q2 of '15 and in the middle of our guidance range. The revenue composition for Q2 is $333 million in system sales, $257 million in support and maintenance, $604 million in services and $22 million in reimbursed travel. 
System sales revenue for the quarter was up 6% compared to Q2 of '15 with strong growth in software being partially offset by a decline in hardware. While hardware did decline year-over-year against a tough comparable, it was up sequentially and in line with expected levels. 
Looking at systems sales margins, it was up 150 basis points over last year, reflecting strong software and lower hardware. 
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 12% compared to Q2 of '15. This is in line with our expectations and continues to reflect good execution via service organizations. Support and maintenance revenue increased 1% over Q2 of '15 reflecting the tough comparable. Support and maintenance is up 5% year-to-date, and we expect similar mid single-digit growth for the rest of the year. 
Looking at revenue by geographic segments, domestic revenue increased 8% over the year-ago quarter to $1.073 billion and non-U.S. revenue grew 9% to $143 million. 
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q2 was 83.1%, which is up from 82.9% in Q2 of '15, reflecting strong software and services and lower hardware. Now I'll discuss spending and operating margin and net earnings. 
For these items, we provide both GAAP and adjusted or non-GAAP results. The adjusted results exclude share-based compensation expense, Health Services related to amortization, acquisition-related deferred revenue and other acquisition-related adjustments, which are detailed and reconciled to GAAP net earnings in our earnings release. 
Looking at operating spending, our second quarter GAAP operating expenses were $769 million compared to $762 million in the year ago period. Adjusted operating expenses were $721 million which is up 9% compared to Q2 of '15. This growth was primarily driven by growth in personnel expense related to revenue-generating associates. The total year-over-year change for each expense category in Q2 on an adjusted basis was 13% growth for sales and client service, 2% decline in software development, 6% growth for G&A and amortization of acquisition-related intangibles was down 12%.
Moving to operating margins. Our Q2 GAAP operating margin was 19.8% compared to 15.3% in the year-ago period. Our adjusted operating margin was 23.8% in Q2, which is down slightly from 24.2% in the year-ago period. This is in line with our previous indication that we expect margin expansion to be limited in 2016, but we do continue to believe we can expand margins 50 to 100 basis points annually after 2016.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q2 were $166 million or $0.48 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $199 million and adjusted diluted EPS was $0.58, which is up 12% compared to Q2 of '15. The Q2 tax rate was 32%, which is in line with our expected range of 32% to 33%. 
Now I'll move to our balance sheet.  We ended Q2 with $720 million of total cash and investments, which is up slightly from $707 million in Q1 with most of our free cash flow being used to repurchase shares. During the quarter, we executed $50 million in stock repurchases, buying back 938,000 shares at an average price of $53.30. Year-to-date, we purchased 3.7 million shares at an average price of $53.41 for a total of $200 million out of the $300 million stock repurchase program authorized in March of this year.
Moving to debt. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations is $585 million, which is down slightly compared to Q1. Total receivables ended the quarter at $983 million, which is up $42 million from Q1. Our Q2 DSO was 74 days, which is an improvement of 2 days compared to Q1 and 7 days better than a year ago.  Operating cash flow for the quarter was $255 million up from $109 million in Q2 of '15 and down from $327 million in Q1. The sequential decline is driven mostly by timing of tax payments and extra payroll in Q2. Year-to-date operating cash flow of $582 million reflects strong growth over $323 million of operating cash flow in the first half of last year.
Q2 capital expenditures were $118 million and capitalized software was $80 million. Free cash flow defined as operating cash flow less capital purchases and capitalized software development cost, was $57 million for the quarter. This is up compared to negative free cash flow in Q2 of '15 and down from a very strong Q1 in '16, due to the lower operating cash flow and higher capital spending related to construction on our new campus. 
Year-to-date free cash flow of $209 million is in line with our expectations, and we expect solid free cash flow for the rest of the year even with spending on our campus remaining elevated. Next year, we expect a decline in capital expenditures resulting in a stronger free cash flow. 
Now I'll go through Q3 and full year 2016 guidance.  For Q3, we expect revenue between $1.2 billion and $1.275 billion with a mid-point reflecting growth of 10% over Q3 of '15. For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.9 billion and $5.0 billion. This range reflects the tightening of our previous range, mostly to capture the lower hardware revenue in the first half of the year, but still 12% full year growth at the mid-point. We expect Q3 diluted EPS to be $0.59 to $0.61 per share with the mid-point reflecting 11% growth over Q3 of '15.
For the full year, we continue to expect adjusted diluted EPS to be $2.30 to $2.40 with a mid-point reflecting 11% growth over 2015. 
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings revenue in Q3 of $1.45 billion to $1.6 billion. The mid-point reflects a slight decline from Q3 '15, which was 44% higher than Q3 of '14, and is by far the toughest comparable period from last year.
The mid-point will still put the year-to-date bookings above 2015, and we expect growth in Q4 as well. So we are still on track for our stated goal of 4 year growth over what was a very strong 2015. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Our bookings were a record for Q2 and only second to our all-time high bookings of Q3 2015. As Marc indicated, our total bookings grew
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Our bookings were a record for Q2 and only second to our all-time high bookings of Q3 2015. As Marc indicated, our total bookings grew 9% despite lower contributions from long-term bookings than last year. The 28% of Q2 2016 bookings from long-term reflects contributions from both ITWorks and managed services, but we're still below the elevated level of 35% in Q2 of 2015. The non long-term portion of Q2 2016 bookings grew 20%, reflecting strong levels of solution and services sales both into our base and to new clients. Bookings this quarter included several large contracts with 45 contracts over $5 million, including 28 over $10 million.
34% of bookings this quarter came from outside our $4 million install base. This high level of new business is a result of an active replacement market, an ongoing success against our primary competitor. The keys to our success continued to be our improved solutions, predictable delivery capabilities, lower cost of ownership, ability to deliver value and our population health and open platform capabilities. I believe that compared favorably to our primary competitor in all of these areas and this is reflected in our run rate. 
Overall, I believe Cerner is viewed as a safe choice for our current solution needs as well as best which is required [ph]  To help clients achieve value from their investments and position them for success as the market shares from a focus on care to a focus on health and wellness.
A good example to opportunity in the marketplace and our competitiveness was Covenant Health selecting Cerner, which we announced last week. Covenant health is 1,900 bed health system based in Eastern Tennessee with 10 hospitals and nearly 100 ambulatory facilities. They will be deploying Cerner Millennium EHR and clinically driven revenue cycle solutions, as well as the HealtheIntent population health solutions across all venues of care. Cerner's integrated solutions across clinical and revenue cycle and acute and ambulatory, proven ability to deliver value and predictable cost and our population health care capabilities were important differentiators for us when competing for this business.
Looking ahead, we believe the replacement market will remain active, given the high number of hospitals on legacy platforms, many of which are being sunset. These opportunities reflected in our leading indicators with the new business pipeline and sales activity at all-time highs. 
Now I'll discuss revenue cycle. We had another great quarter. All new EHR clients included revenue cycles as part of their purchase, reflecting continued focus by the market on clinically driven revenue cycle. This preference is also reflected an ongoing success in our installed base with several more large clients choosing Cerner for acute revenue cycle and a military business office services. 
In addition to a very strong quarter, we also made a great addition to our executive team. As we announced in July, Jeff Hurst will be joining Cerner on September 1 as Senior Vice President of Cerner revenue cycle management and President of Cerner RevWorks. This is a new position and the existing revenue cycle and RevWorks will report to Jeff. Jeff comes with us from Florida Hospital of 2,700 bed acute care medical facility and was a member of the Adventist  health System, where he directed all financial and clinical revenue cycle functions and had a responsibility for key organizational strategies. He is respected industry thought leader and proven executive, and he brings an important provider perspective to Cerner.
As you know, we have made significant investments in revenue cycle that have led to very strong growth in recent years. Our hiring Jeff is an indication that we believe we are still in the early stages of a significant growth opportunity as we help our clients navigate the rapidly evolving reimbursement landscape and that we're investing in talent that will help us capitalize on this opportunity and to contribute to the success of our clients.
Now I'll shift to discussing our population health business, where we had a great quarter. We added several new clients to the HealtheIntent platform, and we also expanded the scope of population health solutions at some of our largest existing clients. Our comprehensive approach to population health remains differentiated in the marketplace, and we continue to add solutions to the HealtheIntent platform. I believe we will continue displaced numerous niche offerings because of the power of the platform and the ability to integrate with the EHR workflow. 
The volume of clients that have purchased initial solutions on our HealtheIntent platform is impressive. We recently passed the 100 client milestone. We believe this positions us for a significant ramp in the revenue in the coming years as these clients add more solutions and lives to the platform, which will increase the per member per month rate and number of members. We expect the driver of this to be ongoing shifts in the reimbursement that are leading to more risk assumption by our clients. And we believe the shift away from traditional fee-for-service is gaining momentum. With the Medicare access and CHIP reauthorization act or MACRA and the new merit based incentive payment systems ramping in coming years as CMS continues to focus on value and quality payments.
Moving to the ambulatory market, where we had record results with strengthened ambulatory EHR, practice management and business office services. Similar to recent quarters, our results include some of the largest acute care clients choosing Cerner's clinical and revenue cycle solutions for their ambulatory settings. 
We also had a strong quarter in the small hospital market. Our cloud-based CommunityWorks offering continues to be competitive against all-niche small hospital vendors. A recent noteworthy win for CommunityWorks was the displacement of a failed attempted go live by a cloud-based vendor that has been making a push in recent years to expand from ambulatory market to hospitals. We have several active opportunities despite the same competitor in both ambulatory and small hospital settings, suggesting their approach is spending about 3x as much on sales and marketing as they do on research and development may not be the most effective approach for the clients.
Outside the U.S., despite some macroeconomic headwinds, we had a good quarter. Non-U.S. revenue grew 9% year-over-year with noteworthy areas of strength, including Australia, Germany and the Middle East. As Mike will discuss, the Middle East strength included ITWorks, which is a positive sign as it highlights a largely untapped global opportunity for ITWorks. 
In summary, I'm please with our execution in Q2 and believe we are well positioned to have a good second half for the year. With that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and Cerner's model experience initiative. I'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client, a large expansion within existing client and a very strong sale
componenttext:
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and Cerner's model experience initiative. I'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client, a large expansion within existing client and a very strong sales back into our client base. Regarding our new client, this client is not only new to ITWorks, but they are a new EHR client as well. And the EHR win displaces our primary competitor. 
The client is a New Children's Hospital in Dubai, and we scheduled to implement our primary competitor solution, but concluded Cerner is a better choice to meet their needs. Our ability to work quickly in order to enable them to be ready for the hospital schedule opening date, as well as provide full IT services through ITWorks, were both the key factors in us being selected. In addition, the success we've had with another client in the region was very helpful in demonstrating the value of the ITWorks model, something our competitor does not offer.
Looking ahead, our pipeline for ITWorks is significant and includes some very large clients. While the timing of ITWorks deals has been lumpy and will likely continue to be, we're confident it will remain a strong contributor to our growth. The value proposition to our clients is very appealing, especially in an environment where they have pressure on operating cost, limited access to IT talent and increasing pressure in light of the industry issues related to security.
Now I'd like to briefly discuss an initiative we call Model Experience. The Model Experience is an extension of the model system, which we have discussed in the past. The Model Experience represents a meaningful shift in our approach to implement our solutions, workflows and standards at our client sites. It presents all of Cerner's standards and content within a controlled environment, where the best practice from workflows and the latest capabilities are captured. Then each client system can be optimized based upon their specific needs. The Model Experience goes beyond just focusing on the EHR. It also provides clients optimal recommendations for leveraging HealtheIntent, Millennium and CareAware solutions.
In addition, the Model Experience uses a continuous advancement approach for adopting recommendations, which ensures our clients will continuously be able to maximize the value of our solutions.
In summary, I believe the Model Experience positions us well for our clients to achieve value from the existing advancements and keep up with the rapidly evolving health care landscape. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question or comment comes from the line of Charles Rhyee from Cowen.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question or comment comes from the line of Charles Rhyee from Cowen.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to talk about the small hospital market, and clearly, you are indicating that you are having a lot of success here downstream in the market. Can you -- what are the characteristics that these smaller hospitals are looking for right now? And what do
componenttext: I want to talk about the small hospital market, and clearly, you are indicating that you are having a lot of success here downstream in the market. Can you -- what are the characteristics that these smaller hospitals are looking for right now? And what do you think is right now really differentiating? Is it the ability to still retain control over how the workflow and how they practice delivering care? Or can you talk abut some of the characteristics when you have discussions with them?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. The characteristics are pretty straightforward. Health care is complex no matter how small the organization is. And so having the depth of a Millennium and Cerner full functioning system, our ability to deliver in a cloud-based environment,
componenttext: This is Zane. The characteristics are pretty straightforward. Health care is complex no matter how small the organization is. And so having the depth of a Millennium and Cerner full functioning system, our ability to deliver in a cloud-based environment, which allows us to have a lower total cost to ownership and a very fixed and predictable model, is very appealing because they need the full functional solutions sets to be able to be delivered in a cost-effective manner. And so those were the kind of the key criteria. Many of them are in a situation where they are forced to leave their legacy provider. And so they are looking for a replacement that takes them to a safe place, as well as put them in good standing from the long stead that connect to -- in the evolving marketplace for health care.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And Marc, if I can talk about how that flows into the model. When you're selling down to the small hospital market in a cloud-based kind of platform, is it a subscription model? And is that -- would that show up in the long-term bookings?
componenttext: That's helpful. And Marc, if I can talk about how that flows into the model. When you're selling down to the small hospital market in a cloud-based kind of platform, is it a subscription model? And is that -- would that show up in the long-term bookings? Or is it because it's still software sale even if its subscription is not counted in the part of the bucket in bookings?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. It is a typical hosting software license arrangement. Sometimes the models are, and it will include subscriptions as well. So it's a our full functioning Millennium solutions that has all the attributes that, that would have. The financial m
componenttext: This is Zane. It is a typical hosting software license arrangement. Sometimes the models are, and it will include subscriptions as well. So it's a our full functioning Millennium solutions that has all the attributes that, that would have. The financial model maybe, from a financing perspective, may look different. But as it relates to bookings, it's going to flow through our model the same way.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, in terms of the pacing of operating margin expansion throughout the year or what's contemplated in sort of the second half guidance. Can you just help us understand in the face of sort of what you did with revenue for the full year, how to th
componenttext: I'm curious, in terms of the pacing of operating margin expansion throughout the year or what's contemplated in sort of the second half guidance. Can you just help us understand in the face of sort of what you did with revenue for the full year, how to think about the other mechanics that would get us to the upper end of the earnings range for the year?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Marc. I think the key thing relative to the revenue guidance was taking out kind of the hardware component or lower hardware that we've seen earlier in the year and then flowing that through the rest. And that's why we took the higher end off
componenttext: Yes, this is Marc. I think the key thing relative to the revenue guidance was taking out kind of the hardware component or lower hardware that we've seen earlier in the year and then flowing that through the rest. And that's why we took the higher end off the revenue. I think, as we roll forward, we still have a year where we expected our margins to be relatively flat year-over-year, and I think that's kind of what we're seeing and what we're delivering. I think that's still our expectations as we roll through. Obviously, to the extent that we increase our higher-margin elements of the business, software, et cetera, there's a chance to increase the operating margins. But I think, overall, given the mix we have, which feels like a pretty good mix between services, software and the rest of our business, I don't know that we're going to have a big change in 2016 relative to margin expansion. I feel very good as we roll into '17, you'll start to see us get back on a track of 50 to 100 basis point of margin expansion that you've seen us historically be able to do. But that's, right now, our view as we look out at the second half of the year, given our guidance for Q3, I think would be relatively flat year-over-year as we continue to see basically low double-digit revenue growth.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I guess, it seems like it implies a little bit of improvement just because you've been down in the first part of this year, that thus the second half had to have a little bit more expansion. But I guess, one other quick things. So on the i
componenttext: That's helpful. I guess, it seems like it implies a little bit of improvement just because you've been down in the first part of this year, that thus the second half had to have a little bit more expansion. But I guess, one other quick things. So on the international business, look like that improved sort of sequentially. Maybe a little bit more color where you're seeing some of the demand there? And then, I guess, how you're thinking about that pacing through the rest of the year because the comps,I think, eased a little bit there?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. As we mentioned in my comments, we saw strength in several areas, but heavily, the Middle East as referenced in Mike's commentary around the ITWorks perspective and Germany as well, we saw good performance there. And I think the peace around
componenttext: This is Zane. As we mentioned in my comments, we saw strength in several areas, but heavily, the Middle East as referenced in Mike's commentary around the ITWorks perspective and Germany as well, we saw good performance there. And I think the peace around the Middle East is very, very pleasing given the price of oil in that marketplace. And really it's a proof point of really good work that's been done by the teams in the Middle East as well as what some of that client had seen here by some of the ITWorks opportunities here that we've worked with in the U.S. So I think that model will continue to have -- create good opportunities for us across the globe.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc, I think we also kind of see a similar traditional markets Australia, Canada, seeing some activity beginning to percolate in the U.K, which is a positive compared to kind of where they've been. So the one place that is not growing a lot more
componenttext: This is Marc, I think we also kind of see a similar traditional markets Australia, Canada, seeing some activity beginning to percolate in the U.K, which is a positive compared to kind of where they've been. So the one place that is not growing a lot more since post the HS. Germany is doing well. but overall, Europe is still an area we think should grow as the economies recover. So -- but we were pleased certainly with the Middle East activity this quarter.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Zane. the -- I think you hit the nail on head in terms of we've seen great market opportunity around the business office services propositions and then really, the extended business office services doing more services along those lines. The
componenttext: Sure, this is Zane. the -- I think you hit the nail on head in terms of we've seen great market opportunity around the business office services propositions and then really, the extended business office services doing more services along those lines. The growth has been very good in both of those areas. As it relates to full outsourcing, we've really taken approach of digesting the clients that we have and really being focused on making sure that the next opportunity is a really good one for us. And we did the EBO services and the business services offices are great entrée into the future of those revenue cycle opportunities. So we still see full revenue cycle outsourcing as a good marketplace for us, but we think it will grow into those markets over time through this -- the business office service and the EBO, which have been very strong in demand.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then on the third quarter bookings guidance. Marc, as you mentioned, you guys are lapping a really big comp there. There was a large ITWorks in professional services contract that was previously discussed and flipped out of the fourth quarter, but again, are either or both of those assumed in the target?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, there's no anticipation that you're going to see our long-term bookings percentage do anything different as you did last year. We saw some mid 30s or even higher percent from long-term. This year, we've been below 30%. I think 30% is probably our targ
componenttext: No, there's no anticipation that you're going to see our long-term bookings percentage do anything different as you did last year. We saw some mid 30s or even higher percent from long-term. This year, we've been below 30%. I think 30% is probably our target. So I think that's where you're going to see [indiscernible] bookings. We don't anticipate any large spikes from any deals that we've talked about before. Those deals are still out there, but I don't know if the Q3 is a timing for either of those at this point.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question or comment comes from the line of Greg Bolan from Avondale Partners.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as I think about the -- Marc, you've talked about setting up well for margin expansion in 2017. Could you maybe just walk us through kind of the variables, the stars that you'd kind of see aligning to set that -- set it up for margin expansion next yea
componenttext: So as I think about the -- Marc, you've talked about setting up well for margin expansion in 2017. Could you maybe just walk us through kind of the variables, the stars that you'd kind of see aligning to set that -- set it up for margin expansion next year?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- for us, the key is continuing seeing the demand in the marketplace obviously, continuing to be able to sell software and sell the high margin elements of the business that we have been seeing. If hardware continues to be at the current
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- for us, the key is continuing seeing the demand in the marketplace obviously, continuing to be able to sell software and sell the high margin elements of the business that we have been seeing. If hardware continues to be at the current level once we get through, that's assuming we can continue to grow the margin as double-digit, which we expect to do, that should improve the overall margins. Historically, you've seen us leverage our spend. You've seen us beverage R&D, growth relative to revenue growth. And those are kind of the drivers that will kind of kick in that you've seen traditionally from -- for us that are driving some of that growth. I think even in our businesses as we do the business model slide every year, you see slight increases in contribution margins from each of those. So if you really just look at our size and the expense components, if you grow R&D slower than revenue and you grow SG&A slower than revenue, it gives you 50 to 100 basis points. So really, as long as we do those 2 things, we should get back on track.

componenttext: Yes. So you guys had great success, It seems like displacing competitors and you [indiscernible] clearly in your data. componenttext: This is Zane. In terms of the economics, they're fairly similar in terms of economics. And depending on the situation where the client is getting out of, you may end up having some more milestone elements and some things around the contracts that maybe a little more challenging for those that have failed to deliver. So sometimes you pay, you have to account for the fact that there have been past failures by others. But for the most part, we're not seeing that broadly in our contracts to-date.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say -- this is Marc. I'd say the milestones, we kind of referenced those maybe a quarter or 2 ago for some very distinct contracts that kind of have the flavor that Zane talked about. Really since then, I can't recall any one that's had a milesto
componenttext: Yes, I'd say -- this is Marc. I'd say the milestones, we kind of referenced those maybe a quarter or 2 ago for some very distinct contracts that kind of have the flavor that Zane talked about. Really since then, I can't recall any one that's had a milestone that was of any significance that would have impacted kind of what we did. So I think certainly, they want to make sure that they're getting what they're paying for. Luckily, our reputation and our ability to deliver is minimizing the contractual requirements that we'd have that would impact the financials for the most part.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then, if I may diverge and ask another question about CommunityWorks and the small hospital market which seems interesting. I know you guys are generating business there both by displacing competitors and, I guess, migrating Health Services clients as well. Roughly speaking, how much of your growth there is one versus the other? Is it mainly sort of migrating Health Services client or is it more displacing competitors? If you could give us a rough sense for the market.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Zane. It's actually coming mostly from the displacement of other competitors. We have had great success on the Health Services migrations in lower end of the marketplace. And our win rate for those in the high 90s, 90 percentile for that cli
componenttext: Sure, this is Zane. It's actually coming mostly from the displacement of other competitors. We have had great success on the Health Services migrations in lower end of the marketplace. And our win rate for those in the high 90s, 90 percentile for that client base has been very successful, but the bulk of it is coming at the expense of replacing our competitors.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And that business is growing obviously?
componenttext: Got it. And that business is growing obviously?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: And that businesses continues to grow. We're on track for our best year yet.

componenttextpreview: Steve, right now, 100% of those were being charged, signed on a PMPM basis. Once again, a lot of them are kind of smaller pilots, but we want to introduce that payment model. And I think because the advantage to what's from that model is, as they expand P
componenttext: Steve, right now, 100% of those were being charged, signed on a PMPM basis. Once again, a lot of them are kind of smaller pilots, but we want to introduce that payment model. And I think because the advantage to what's from that model is, as they expand PMPM for the applications they have signed up for, they expand applications, they expand members, the PMPM natural grows that revenue stream. So that's why we go to market that way.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: And do the clients ask for traditional software model or is it just not an option?

componenttext: This is Zane, What you'll see is once you educate people through the difference in what they need over time, is the content ever-changing, the hosted element of it, the true cloud-based platform. So it's not -- it doesn't have the same characteristics as their former models have had. So -- and most of our clients are getting comfortable with that type of model for cloud-based offerings.

componenttext: Yes. I don't have a timeframe in my head. I think what becomes a bigger enough number, that it makes a difference kind of from the analysis, but once again, because of the size of most of these deals, we haven't reached there. And I don't know that I can give you a date by which we'll reach that. But certainly, when it become something that is notable and the likelihood is when it gets to kind of a level where it becomes notable, it's going to be on a fairly high growth trajectory. So...

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: I guess, Zane, if we talk about the Health Services base, typically in M&A and the space you see it, it accelerates kind of a go forward decision-making process. What percentage of the Health Services base do you think has kind of made a go forward platform decision? And what is the retention there look like?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- I don't -- George, I don't have the exact numbers handy in terms of it as it relates to the exact numbers that have made a go-forward decision. So I have to provide that to you later. As it relates to the win rates, I can tell you that we modeled o
componenttext: The -- I don't -- George, I don't have the exact numbers handy in terms of it as it relates to the exact numbers that have made a go-forward decision. So I have to provide that to you later. As it relates to the win rates, I can tell you that we modeled out as part of the acquisition where we anticipated those what our win rates would look like and those had mirrored what our expectations had been almost exactly in terms of where we thought we would end up in a smaller end of the spectrum to the large end of our spectrum. So our win rate has been actually quite high in the low end. And then in the larger upper end, it's been -- it's little bit north of our traditional win rate.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Again, Marc, I guess, my quick follow-up would be is -- it sounds like the retention has been in line with expectations, but we know that there's been some churn. I guess. Can you talk me through the synergy delivery and have the synergies on the de
componenttext: Okay. Again, Marc, I guess, my quick follow-up would be is -- it sounds like the retention has been in line with expectations, but we know that there's been some churn. I guess. Can you talk me through the synergy delivery and have the synergies on the deal thus far have been delivered? Or has some of the churn in the client base eaten away at some of the synergy opportunity? And I guess, just trying to think about returns on the deal and whether or not the deal is measuring up to expectations.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Keep in mind, certainly, when we bought them and closed, they already a small group of clients that have decided and notified Siemens that they were leaving the fold. Every one of those is still writing me their monthly check or others made their mo
componenttext: Sure. Keep in mind, certainly, when we bought them and closed, they already a small group of clients that have decided and notified Siemens that they were leaving the fold. Every one of those is still writing me their monthly check or others made their monthly check for their contract duration, which can extend from anywhere from 3 to 5 more years. So the impact of a client's making decision to leave actually tails off -- has a very long tail to it. So from our business model perspective and certainly, in the near-term that we've been working through, the synergies primarily as we talked about were costs related. And I think we've done a very good job of delivering on those cost synergies. So I think, overall, if you look at the kind of the bottom line of HS, we are ahead relative to an OE, slightly ahead of where we would have modeled ourselves. I think we're slightly ahead of where we would have expected from retention standpoint. So today, we're actually very pleased at how it's modeling out and how these clients are starting to really get into the Cerner mode and see us as their provider moving their allegiance over from the HS folks. So today, things are working very well.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: I guess, maybe, Marc, on the support maintenance line. I know you said kind of mid-single-digit growth or somewhere thereabouts the rest of the year. It's a little bit of a slow down. Is this just the low of large numbers? Or is there any change in the way you're signing contracts that would be creating any headwind for that line?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, there are no change in how we bill or how we sign contracts relative to support maintenance. The HS acquisition obviously came in, bought a big bolus [ph]  Of support dollars there. They came in Q2 a year ago. Those dollars were a little bit higher. T
componenttext: No, there are no change in how we bill or how we sign contracts relative to support maintenance. The HS acquisition obviously came in, bought a big bolus [ph]  Of support dollars there. They came in Q2 a year ago. Those dollars were a little bit higher. They were a little bit lower in Q3 and then kind of evened out as we move forward. So that's -- when you look at this quarter, there's a little bit of a lower percent increase. But based on the size and the law of large numbers and basically, we continue to turn on projects is our normal pace. You kind of go and look at if that number gets large somewhere in the mid-single digits growth on that line.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then maybe just as far as the guidance is concerned. If I kind of take what you've done year-to-date and not back up, what your guidance is for 3Q? There's a decent step-up in the fourth quarter to get to the mid-point of the annual revenue guidance
componenttext: Okay. Then maybe just as far as the guidance is concerned. If I kind of take what you've done year-to-date and not back up, what your guidance is for 3Q? There's a decent step-up in the fourth quarter to get to the mid-point of the annual revenue guidance. Is there anything notable that would be occurring in the fourth quarter that would get us to that number like an unusually strong hardware quarter, anything like that, that we should be keeping in mind?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- there's nothing from a hardware perspective. We -- I am past the time when I am counting on our to deliver anything from my top line. So no, that's just the strength of business. A little bit of Q4 impact. We are getting into a time when yo
componenttext: No, I don't -- there's nothing from a hardware perspective. We -- I am past the time when I am counting on our to deliver anything from my top line. So no, that's just the strength of business. A little bit of Q4 impact. We are getting into a time when you're seeing a little more of the cyclical nature of the business, where we had traditional strong Q4. I think, as we look at the backlog, as we do all the analysis that we do from our forecast meetings and forecast, not only the next quarter, but obviously, 3 more quarters out, Q4 is just lined up to be a good solid quarter with nothing unique driving that revenue increase. It's just the business and driving the revenue out of the backlog.

componenttext: Maybe to follow up on Jamie's question a little bit there. And Marc, you seem to allude to this a little bit already. But curious whether it will return to the traditional seasonality of the business here in Q4 and really specifically in terms of bookings?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as we look at Q4, the -- some of the seasonality we see on the income side, you'll see it. Certainly, we expect Q4 to be traditionally a little bit stronger bookings quarter. I think Q3, our guidance is that we're going to actually have a r
componenttext: Well, I think, as we look at Q4, the -- some of the seasonality we see on the income side, you'll see it. Certainly, we expect Q4 to be traditionally a little bit stronger bookings quarter. I think Q3, our guidance is that we're going to actually have a really good bookings quarter. It's just against the comp that went up 44% in the year ago quarter. So I think we're -- once again, we don't talk about bookings outside of the oncoming quarter. But we are very comfortable that for the full year, we have expect-to-grow bookings. And so, obviously, to do that, we'd expect to have a pretty decent Q4.

componenttext: Fair enough. One more for me. We're coming up on almost a year of the announcement of the population health win from an epic customer, Geisinger Health. componenttext: So this is Zane. We've actually had a number of the clients that have made HealtheIntent decisions and signed contracts. And we just have not disclosed those separately from that. So we do continue to see that trend. We have a number of opportunities on our pipeline that we continue to work in the success with our clients in that -- with our pop health clients in that space is garnering a lot of interest in that client base.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Zane, maybe a follow-up to your comment about --. I think you said all of the people that are purchasing the Cerner Millennium platform on the clinicals are now -- are also purchasing the revenue cycle product. I'm just curious if you can give us sort of any either qualitative or quantitative numbers in terms of, over the last couple of years, how that's trended and then how many have actually implemented? versus  [indiscernible] and how many you're going sort of big bang? Are they doing clinicals and they wait a couple of years and then they come back to revenue cycle?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, this is Marc. Just to kind of set the stage. While people, revenue cycle is very active, about 25% of our base has revenue cycle. So while it's been very active recently, it is -- it's still a very low level of penetration into our base. So that's j
componenttext: Alex, this is Marc. Just to kind of set the stage. While people, revenue cycle is very active, about 25% of our base has revenue cycle. So while it's been very active recently, it is -- it's still a very low level of penetration into our base. So that's just from a perspective, we're doing really well. We still have a lot of runway left.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Marc is referring to our installed base overall, which -- but most -- I think what you've seen over the last couple of year has been integrated revenue cycle, clinical and revenue cycle decision, and that number has continued to inch up where this
componenttext: Yes, so Marc is referring to our installed base overall, which -- but most -- I think what you've seen over the last couple of year has been integrated revenue cycle, clinical and revenue cycle decision, and that number has continued to inch up where this quarter was 100% of them selecting revenue cycle as part of that. And the -- from an implementation perspective, we are into thousands of ambulatory providers. We're into the hundreds of Cerner Millennium sites. So lots of scale across different sizes of organizations. So from small to extremely large organizations running Cerner revenue cycle across that and that's helped with a credibility of the solution side as we move forward. As it relates to individual projects, those really come down to the individual client situation themselves. Many are big bang model. And so I would say half of those are big bang. And I would say the other half, they have some phased approach based on what their risk tolerance is, what the sunset solutions are that they're facing and what the key criteria that they're looking at operationally to solve. So those come down to individual client base decision.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is August 2, 2016, and this call is being recorded.The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, inclu
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Second Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is August 2, 2016, and this call is being recorded.
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including, without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating and capital expenses, product development, new markets or prospects for the company's solutions and services and plans and expectations related to the Health Services business and other clients' achievements.
Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filings.  A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in the earnings call can be found in the company's earnings release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted on the Investors Section of cerner.com.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call.  I will lead off today with a review of the numbers; Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with results highlights and marketplace observations; and then Mike Nill, our Chief Operat
componenttext:
Thank you, Howard. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call.  I will lead off today with a review of the numbers; Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with results highlights and marketplace observations; and then Mike Nill, our Chief Operating Officer will provide some additional highlights. 
Now I will turn to our results, which were solid across all key metrics. Our bookings revenue in Q2 is $1.4 billion, which reflects 9% growth over Q2 of '15. Note that this growth was driven on only 28% of bookings coming from long-term contracts in Q2 of '16 compared to 35% in the year-ago quarter. 
Our revenue backlog ended the quarter at $15.0 billion, which is up 13% from $13.3 billion a year ago. Revenue in the quarter was $1.22 billion, which is up 8% over Q2 of '15 and in the middle of our guidance range. The revenue composition for Q2 is $333 million in system sales, $257 million in support and maintenance, $604 million in services and $22 million in reimbursed travel. 
System sales revenue for the quarter was up 6% compared to Q2 of '15 with strong growth in software being partially offset by a decline in hardware. While hardware did decline year-over-year against a tough comparable, it was up sequentially and in line with expected levels. 
Looking at systems sales margins, it was up 150 basis points over last year, reflecting strong software and lower hardware. 
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 12% compared to Q2 of '15. This is in line with our expectation and continues to reflect good execution via service organizations. Support and maintenance revenue increased 1% over Q2 of '15 reflecting the tough comparable. Support and maintenance is up 5% year-to-date, and we expect similar mid-single-digit growth for the rest of the year. 
Looking at revenue by geographic segments. Domestic revenue increased 8% over the year-ago quarter to $1.073 billion and non-U.S. revenue grew 9% to $143 million. 
Moving to gross margin. Our gross margin for Q2 was 83.1%, which is up from 82.9% in Q2 of '15, reflecting strong software and services and lower hardware. 
Now I'll discuss spending and operating margin and net earnings. For these items, we provide both GAAP and adjusted or non-GAAP results. The adjusted results exclude share-based compensation expense, Health Services related to amortization, acquisition-related deferred revenue and other acquisition-related adjustments, which are detailed and reconciled to GAAP net earnings in our earnings release. 
Looking at operating spending, our second quarter GAAP operating expenses were $769 million compared to $762 million in the year-ago period. Adjusted operating expenses were $721 million which is up 9% compared to Q2 of '15. This growth was primarily driven by growth in personnel expense related to revenue-generating associates. The total year-over-year change for each expense category in Q2 on an adjusted basis was 13% growth for sales and client service, 2% decline in software development, 6% growth for G&A and amortization of acquisition-related intangibles was down 12%.
Moving to operating margins. Our Q2 GAAP operating margin was 19.8% compared to 15.3% in the year-ago period. Our adjusted operating margin was 23.8% in Q2, which is down slightly from 24.2% in the year-ago period. This is in line with our previous indication that we expect margin expansion to be limited in 2016, but we do continue to believe we can expand margins 50 to 100 basis points annually after 2016.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q2 were $166 million or $0.48 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $199 million and adjusted diluted EPS was $0.58, which is up 12% compared to Q2 of '15. 
The Q2 tax rate was 32%, which is in line with our expected range of 32% to 33%. 
Now I'll move to our balance sheet.  We ended Q2 with $720 million of total cash and investments, which is up slightly from $707 million in Q1 with most of our free cash flow being used to repurchase shares. During the quarter, we executed $50 million in stock repurchases, buying back 938,000 shares at an average price of $53.30. Year-to-date, we have purchased 3.7 million shares at an average price of $53.41 for a total of $200 million out of the $300 million stock repurchase program authorized in March of this year.
Moving to debt. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations is $585 million, which is down slightly compared to Q1. Total receivables ended the quarter at $983 million, which is up $42 million from Q1. Our Q2 DSO was 74 days, which is an improvement of 2 days compared to Q1 and 7 days better than a year ago. Operating cash flow for the quarter was $255 million up from $109 million in Q2 of '15 and down from $327 million in Q1. The sequential decline is driven mostly by timing of tax payments and extra payroll in Q2. Year-to-date operating cash flow of $582 million reflects strong growth over $323 million of operating cash flow in the first half of last year.
Q2 capital expenditures were $118 million and capitalized software was $80 million. Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital purchases and capitalized software development costs, was $57 million for the quarter. This is up compared to negative free cash flow in Q2 of '15 and down from a very strong Q1 in '16, due to the lower operating cash flow and higher capital spending related to construction on our new campus. 
Year-to-date free cash flow of $209 million is in line with our expectations, and we expect solid free cash flow for the rest of the year even with spending on our campus remaining elevated. Next year, we expect a decline in capital expenditures resulting in a stronger free cash flow. 
Now I'll go through Q3 and full year 2016 guidance. For Q3, we expect revenue between $1.2 billion and $1.275 billion with the mid-point reflecting growth of 10% over Q3 of '15. For the full year, we expect revenue between $4.9 billion and $5.0 billion. This range reflects the tightening of our previous range, mostly to capture the lower hardware revenue in the first half of the year, but is still 12% full year growth at the mid-point. We expect Q3 diluted EPS to be $0.59 to $0.61 per share with the mid-point reflecting 11% growth over Q3 of '15.
For the full year, we continue to expect adjusted diluted EPS to be $2.30 to $2.40 with the mid-point reflecting 11% growth over 2015. 
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings revenue in Q3 of $1.45 billion to $1.6 billion. The mid-point reflects a slight decline from Q3 '15, which was 44% higher than Q3 of '14, and is by far the toughest comparable period from last year.
The mid-point will still put the year-to-date bookings above 2015, and we expect growth in Q4 as well. So we are still on track for our stated goal of full year growth over what was a very strong 2015. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Our bookings were a record for Q2 and only second to our all-time high bookings of Q3 2015. As Marc indicated, our total bookings grew
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color on our results and make some marketplace observations. Our bookings were a record for Q2 and only second to our all-time high bookings of Q3 2015. As Marc indicated, our total bookings grew 9% despite lower contributions from long-term bookings than last year. The 28% of Q2 2016 bookings from long term reflects contributions from both ITWorks and managed services, but were still below the elevated level of 35% in Q2 of 2015. The non-long term portion of Q2 2016 bookings grew 20%, reflecting strong levels of solution and services sales both into our base and to new clients. 
Bookings this quarter included several large contracts with 45 contracts over $5 million, including 28 over $10 million. 34% of bookings this quarter came from outside our $4 million install base. This high level of new business is a result of an active replacement market and ongoing success against our primary competitor. The keys to our success continue to be our improved solutions, predictable delivery capabilities, lower cost of ownership, ability to deliver value and our population health and open platform capabilities. I believe we compare favorably to our primary competitor in all of these areas and this is reflected in our run rate. 
Overall, I believe Cerner is viewed as the safe choice for our current solution needs, as well as best positioned supplier to help clients achieve value from their investments and position them for success as the market shifts from a focus on care to a focus on health and wellness.
A good example of the opportunity in the marketplace and our competitiveness was Covenant Health selecting Cerner, which we announced last week. Covenant Health is a 1,900 bed health system based in Eastern Tennessee, with 10 hospitals and nearly 100 ambulatory facilities. They will be deploying Cerner Millennium EHR and clinically driven revenue cycle solutions, as well as the HealtheIntent population health solutions across all venues of care. Cerner's integrated solutions across clinical and revenue cycle and acute and ambulatory, proven ability to deliver value at a predictable cost and our population health care capabilities were important differentiators for us when competing for this business.
Looking ahead, we believe the replacement market will remain active, given the high number of hospitals on legacy platforms, many of which are being sunset. This opportunity is reflected in our leading indicators with our new business pipeline and sales activities at all-time highs. 
Now I'll discuss revenue cycle. We had another great quarter. All new EHR clients included revenue cycle as part of their purchase, reflecting continued focus by the market on clinically driven revenue cycle. This preference was also reflected in ongoing success in our installed base with several more large clients choosing Cerner for acute revenue cycle and a military business office services. 
In addition to a very strong quarter, we also made a great addition to our executive team. As we announced in July, Jeff Hurst will be joining Cerner on September 1 as Senior Vice President of Cerner revenue cycle management and President of Cerner RevWorks. This is a new position and the existing revenue cycle and RevWorks teams will report to Jeff. Jeff comes to us from Florida Hospital, a 2,700 bed acute care medical facility that is a member of the Adventist Health System, where he directed all financial and clinical revenue cycle functions and had a responsibility for key organizational strategies. He is respected industry thought leader and a proven executive, and he brings an important provider perspective to Cerner.
As you know, we have made significant investments in revenue cycle that have led to very strong growth in recent years. Our hiring of Jeff is an indication that we believe we are still in the early stages of a significant growth opportunity as we help our clients navigate the rapidly evolving reimbursement landscape and that we're investing in talent that will help us capitalize on this opportunity and to contribute to the success of our clients.
Now I'll shift to discussing our population health business, where we had a great quarter. We added several new clients to the HealtheIntent platform, and we also expanded the scope of population health solutions at some of our largest existing clients. Our comprehensive approach to population health remains differentiated in the marketplace, and we continue to add solutions to the HealtheIntent platform. I believe we'll continue displaced numerous niche offerings because of the power of the platform and the ability to integrate with the EHR workflow. 
The volume of clients that have purchased initial solutions on our HealtheIntent platform is impressive. We recently passed the 100 client milestone. We believe this positions us for a significant ramp in the revenue in the coming years as these clients add more solutions and lives to the platform, which will increase the per member per month rate and number of members. We expect the driver of this to be ongoing shifts in reimbursement that are leading to more risk assumption by our clients. And we believe the shift away from traditional fee-for-service is gaining momentum with the Medicare Access and CHIP Reauthorization Act or MACRA and the new merit-based incentive payment systems ramping in coming years as CMS continues to focus on value and quality payments.
Moving to the ambulatory market, where we had record results with strengthened ambulatory EHR, practice management and business office services. Similar to the recent quarters, our results include some of the largest acute care clients choosing Cerner's clinical and revenue cycle solutions for their ambulatory settings. 
We also had a strong quarter in the small hospital market. Our cloud-based CommunityWorks offering continues to be competitive against all-niche small hospital vendors. A recent noteworthy win for CommunityWorks was the displacement of a failed attempted go live by a cloud-based vendor that has been making a push in recent years to expand from ambulatory market to hospitals. We have several active opportunities displace the same competitor in both ambulatory and small hospital settings, suggesting their approach of spending about 3x as much on sales and marketing as they do on research and development may not be the most effective approach for the client.
Outside the U.S., despite some macroeconomic headwinds, we had a good quarter. Non-U.S. revenue grew 9% year-over-year with noteworthy areas of strength, including Australia, Germany and the Middle East. As Mike will discuss, the Middle East strength included ITWorks, which is a positive sign as it highlights a largely untapped global opportunity for ITWorks. 
In summary, I'm pleased with our execution in Q2 and believe we are well positioned to have a good second half for the year. With that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and Cerner's model experience initiative. I'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client, a large expansion with an existing client and a very strong sal
componenttext:
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'm going to discuss ITWorks and Cerner's model experience initiative. I'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client, a large expansion with an existing client and a very strong sales back into our client base. Regarding our new client, this client is not only new to ITWorks, but they are a new EHR client as well. And the EHR win displaces our primary competitor. 
The client is the new children's hospital in Dubai, and was scheduled to implement our primary competitor's solution, but concluded Cerner is a better choice to meet their needs. Our ability to work quickly in order to enable them to be ready for the hospital schedule opening date, as well as provide full IT services through ITWorks, were both key factors in us being selected. In addition, the success we've had with another client in the region was very helpful in demonstrating the value of the ITWorks model, something our competitor does not offer.
Looking ahead, our pipeline for ITWorks is significant and includes some very large clients. While the timing of ITWorks deals has been lumpy and will likely continue to be, we're confident it will remain a strong contributor to our growth. The value proposition to our clients is very appealing, especially in an environment where they have pressure on operating cost, limited access to IT talent and increasing pressure in light of the industry issues related to security.
Now I'd like to briefly discuss an initiative we call Model Experience. The Model Experience is an extension of the model system, which we have discussed in the past. The Model Experience represents a meaningful shift in our approach to implement our solutions, workflows and standards at our client sites. It presents all of Cerner's standards and content within a controlled environment, where the best practice for workflows and the latest capabilities are captured, then each client system can be optimized based upon their specific needs. The Model Experience goes beyond just focusing on the EHR. It also provides clients optimal recommendations for leveraging HealtheIntent, Millennium and CareAware solutions.
In addition, the Model Experience uses a continuous advancement approach for adopting recommendations, which ensures our clients will continuously be able to maximize the value of our solutions.
In summary, I believe the Model Experience positions us well for our clients to achieve value from their existing investments and keep up with the rapidly evolving health care landscape. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question or comment comes from the line of Charles Rhyee from Cowen.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question or comment comes from the line of Charles Rhyee from Cowen.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about the small hospital market, and clearly, you're indicating that you're having a lot of success here downstream in the market. Can you -- what are the characteristics that these smaller hospitals are looking for right now? And what do
componenttext: I wanted to talk about the small hospital market, and clearly, you're indicating that you're having a lot of success here downstream in the market. Can you -- what are the characteristics that these smaller hospitals are looking for right now? And what do you think is right now really differentiating? Is it the ability to still retain control over how their workflow and how they practice delivering care? Or can you talk about some of the characteristics when you're in discussions with them?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. The characteristics are pretty straightforward. Health care is complex no matter how small the organization is. And so having the depth of a Millennium and Cerner full functioning system, our ability to deliver in a cloud-based environment,
componenttext: This is Zane. The characteristics are pretty straightforward. Health care is complex no matter how small the organization is. And so having the depth of a Millennium and Cerner full functioning system, our ability to deliver in a cloud-based environment, which allows us to have a lower total cost to ownership and a very fixed and predictable model, is very appealing because they need the full functioning solution set to be able to be delivered in a cost-effective manner. And so those were the kind of the key criteria. Many of them are in a situation where they are forced to leave their legacy provider. And so they're looking for a replacement that takes them to a safe place, as well as puts them in good standing from the long stead to connect to -- in the evolving marketplace for health care.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And, Marc, if I can talk about how that flows into the model. When you're selling down to the small hospital market in a cloud-based kind of platform, is it a subscription model? And is that -- would that show up in the long-term bookings?
componenttext: That's helpful. And, Marc, if I can talk about how that flows into the model. When you're selling down to the small hospital market in a cloud-based kind of platform, is it a subscription model? And is that -- would that show up in the long-term bookings? Or is it because it's still software sale, even if it's subscription, it's not counted in that part of the bucket in bookings?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. It is a typical hosting software license arrangement. Sometimes the models are, and it will include subscriptions as well. So it's our full functioning Millennium solution set that has all the attributes that, that would have. The financial
componenttext: This is Zane. It is a typical hosting software license arrangement. Sometimes the models are, and it will include subscriptions as well. So it's our full functioning Millennium solution set that has all the attributes that, that would have. The financial model maybe -- from a financing perspective, may look different. But as it relates to bookings, it's going to flow through our model the same way.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the long-term component is smaller because the hosting is not as big a component of those deals.
componenttext: So the long-term component is smaller because the hosting is not as big a component of those deals.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious, in terms of the pacing of operating margin expansion throughout the year or what's contemplated in sort of the second half guidance, can you just help us understand it in the face of sort of what you did with revenue for the full year, how to
componenttext: I'm curious, in terms of the pacing of operating margin expansion throughout the year or what's contemplated in sort of the second half guidance, can you just help us understand it in the face of sort of what you did with revenue for the full year, how to think about the other mechanics that would get us to the upper end of the earnings range for the year?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Marc. I think the key thing relative to the revenue guidance was taking out kind of the hardware component, the lower hardware that we'd seen earlier in the year, and then flowing that through the rest. And that's why we took the higher end o
componenttext: Yes, this is Marc. I think the key thing relative to the revenue guidance was taking out kind of the hardware component, the lower hardware that we'd seen earlier in the year, and then flowing that through the rest. And that's why we took the higher end off the revenue. I think as we roll forward, we still have a year where we expect that our margins to be relatively flat year-over-year, and I think that's kind of what we're seeing and what we're delivering. I think that's still our expectations as we roll through. Obviously, to the extent that we increase our higher-margin elements of the business, software, et cetera, there's a chance to increase the operating margins. But I think, overall, given the mix we have, which feels like a pretty good mix between services, software and the rest of our business, I don't know that we're going to have a big change in 2016 relative to margin expansion. I feel very good as we roll into '17, you'll start to see us get back on a track of the 50 to 100 basis points of margin expansion that you've seen us historically be able to do. But that's, right now, our view as we look out at the second half of the year, given our guidance for Q3, I think would be relatively flat year-over-year as we continue to see basically low double-digit revenue growth.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. I guess we'll have -- well, guys, it seems like it implies a little bit of improvement just because you've been down in the first part of this year, that thus the second half has to have a little bit more expansion. But I guess, one other
componenttext: That's helpful. I guess we'll have -- well, guys, it seems like it implies a little bit of improvement just because you've been down in the first part of this year, that thus the second half has to have a little bit more expansion. But I guess, one other quick thing. So on the international business, looked like that improved sort of sequentially. Maybe a little bit more color where you're seeing some of the demand there? And then, I guess, how you're thinking about that pacing through the rest of the year because the comps, I think, eased a little bit there?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Zane. Ross, so the -- as we mentioned in my comments, we saw strength in several areas, but heavily, the Middle East as referenced in Mike's commentary around the ITWorks perspective and Germany as well, we saw good performance there. And I think
componenttext: This is Zane. Ross, so the -- as we mentioned in my comments, we saw strength in several areas, but heavily, the Middle East as referenced in Mike's commentary around the ITWorks perspective and Germany as well, we saw good performance there. And I think the piece around the Middle East is very, very pleasing given the price of oil in that marketplace. And really, it's a proof point of really good work that's been done by the teams in the Middle East, as well as what some of that client had seen here by some of the ITWorks opportunities here that we've worked with in the U.S. So I think that model will continue to have -- create good opportunities for us across the globe.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Marc. I think we also kind of see in some of our traditional markets, Australia, Canada, seeing some activity beginning to percolate in the U.K, which is a positive compared to kind of where they've been. So the one place that's not growing a lot
componenttext: This is Marc. I think we also kind of see in some of our traditional markets, Australia, Canada, seeing some activity beginning to percolate in the U.K, which is a positive compared to kind of where they've been. So the one place that's not growing a lot more since post the HS, Germany's doing well, but overall, Europe is still an area we think should grow as those economies recover. So -- but we were pleased certainly with the Middle East activity this quarter.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is Zane. The -- I think you hit the nail on head in terms of we've seen great market opportunity around the business office services propositions and then really, the extended business office services doing more services along those lines. The
componenttext: Sure, this is Zane. The -- I think you hit the nail on head in terms of we've seen great market opportunity around the business office services propositions and then really, the extended business office services doing more services along those lines. The growth has been very good in both of those areas. As it relates to full outsourcing, we've really taken approach of digesting the clients that we have and really being focused on making sure that the next opportunity is a really good one for us. And we think the EBO services and the business office service are great entrée into the future of those revenue cycle opportunities. So we see -- we still see full revenue cycle outsourcing as a good marketplace for us, but we think it will grow into those markets over time through this -- the business office service and the EBO, which have been very strong in demand.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
