headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, maybe, Marc, on the support maintenance line. I know you said kind of mid-single-digit growth or somewhere thereabouts the rest of the year. It's a little bit of a slowdown. Is this just the law of large numbers? Or is there any change in the way
componenttext: I guess, maybe, Marc, on the support maintenance line. I know you said kind of mid-single-digit growth or somewhere thereabouts the rest of the year. It's a little bit of a slowdown. Is this just the law of large numbers? Or is there any change in the way you're signing contracts that would be creating any headwind for that line?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, there's no change in how we bill or how we sign contracts relative to support maintenance. The HS acquisition obviously came in, bought a big bolus of support dollars there that came in Q2 a year ago. Those dollars were a little bit higher. They were
componenttext: No, there's no change in how we bill or how we sign contracts relative to support maintenance. The HS acquisition obviously came in, bought a big bolus of support dollars there that came in Q2 a year ago. Those dollars were a little bit higher. They were a little bit lower in Q3 and then kind of evened out as we rolled forward. So that's -- when you look at this quarter, there's a little bit of a lower percent increase. But based on the size and the law of large numbers and basically, as we continue to turn on projects at our normal pace. You kind of go and look at it, that number gets large somewhere in the mid-single digits growth on that line.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just as far as the guidance is concerned, if I kind of take what you've done year-to-date, not back out what your guidance is for 3Q, there's a decent step-up in the fourth quarter to get to the mid-point of the annual revenue guidanc
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just as far as the guidance is concerned, if I kind of take what you've done year-to-date, not back out what your guidance is for 3Q, there's a decent step-up in the fourth quarter to get to the mid-point of the annual revenue guidance. Is there anything notable that would be occurring in the fourth quarter that would get us to that number, like an unusually strong hardware quarter or anything like that, that we should be keeping in mind?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't -- there's nothing from a hardware perspective. We -- I am past the time when I am counting on hardware to deliver anything to my top line. So no, that's just the strength of business. A little bit of Q4 impact. We are getting into a time when
componenttext: No, I don't -- there's nothing from a hardware perspective. We -- I am past the time when I am counting on hardware to deliver anything to my top line. So no, that's just the strength of business. A little bit of Q4 impact. We are getting into a time when you're seeing a little more of the cyclical nature of the business, where we had traditional strong Q4. I think, as we look at the backlog, as we do all the analysis that we do from our forecast meetings and forecasts, not only the next quarter, but obviously, 3 more quarters out, Q4 is just lining up to be a good solid quarter with nothing unique driving that revenue increase. It's just the business and driving the revenue out of the backlog.

componenttext: Maybe to follow up on Jamie's question a little bit there. And, Marc, you seem to allude to this a little bit already. But curious whether we'll return to the traditional seasonality of the business here in Q4 and really specifically in terms of bookings?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that as we look at Q4, the -- some of the seasonality we see on the income side, you'll see it. Certainly, we expect Q4 to be traditionally a little bit stronger bookings quarter. I think Q3, our guidance is that we're going to actually have
componenttext: Well, I think that as we look at Q4, the -- some of the seasonality we see on the income side, you'll see it. Certainly, we expect Q4 to be traditionally a little bit stronger bookings quarter. I think Q3, our guidance is that we're going to actually have a really good bookings quarter. It's just against the comp that went up 44% in the year-ago quarter. So I think we're -- once again, we don't talk about bookings outside of the oncoming quarter. But we're very comfortable that for the full year, we'd expect to grow bookings. And so, obviously, to do that, we'd expect to have a pretty decent Q4.

componenttext: So this is Zane. We've actually had a number of Epic clients that have made HealtheIntent decisions and signed contracts. And we just have not disclosed those separately from that. So we do continue to see that trend. We have a number of opportunities in our pipeline that we continue to work and the success with our clients in that -- with our pop health clients in that space is garnering a lot of interest in that client base.

componenttext: Zane, maybe a follow-up to your comment about -- I think you said all of the people that are purchasing the Cerner Millennium platform on the clinicals are now -- are also purchasing the revenue cycle product. I'm just curious if you can give us sort of any either qualitative or quantitative numbers in terms of, over the last couple of years, how that's trended and then how many have actually implemented versus 2 billion per minute [ph] and how many are going sort of big bang? Are they doing clinicals and they wait a couple of years and then they come back to revenue cycle?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandy, this is Marc. Just to kind of set the stage. While people, revenue cycle is very active, about 25% of our base has revenue cycle. So while it's been very active recently, it is -- it's still a very low level of penetration into our base. So that's
componenttext: Sandy, this is Marc. Just to kind of set the stage. While people, revenue cycle is very active, about 25% of our base has revenue cycle. So while it's been very active recently, it is -- it's still a very low level of penetration into our base. So that's just from a perspective, it's -- while we're doing really well, we still have a lot of runway left.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Marc's referring to our installed base overall, which -- but most -- I think what you've seen over the last couple of years has been integrated revenue cycle, clinical and revenue cycle decision, and that number has continued to inch up where this
componenttext: Yes, so Marc's referring to our installed base overall, which -- but most -- I think what you've seen over the last couple of years has been integrated revenue cycle, clinical and revenue cycle decision, and that number has continued to inch up where this quarter was 100% of them selecting revenue cycle as part of that. And the -- from an implementation perspective, we're into thousands of ambulatory providers. We're into the hundreds of Cerner Millennium sites, so lots of scale across different sizes of organizations. So from small to extremely large organizations running Cerner revenue cycle across that and that's helped with the credibility of the solution side as we move forward. As it relates to individual projects, those really come down to the individual client situation themselves. Many are big bang model. And so I would say half of those are big bang. And I would say the other half, they have some phased approach based on what their risk tolerance is, what the sunset solutions are that they're facing and what the key criteria that they're looking at operationally to solve. So those come down to individual client base decision.

componenttext: Individually, all of those kinds of things could impact any individual deal. But as can happen with any individual particular deal, there can be a number of circumstances that impact that individual situation. But from a macro perspective, the trend lines have stayed the same on the conversion time.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is November 1, 2016, and this call is being recorded.The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, incl
componenttext:
Welcome to Cerner Corporation's Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. Today's date is November 1, 2016, and this call is being recorded.
The company has asked me to remind you that various remarks made here today constitute forward-looking statements, including without limitation, those regarding projections of future revenues or earnings, operating margins, operating capital expenses, product development, new product or prospects of the company's solutions and services and plans and expectations related to Health Services business and other clients' achievements.
Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by the forward-looking statements. Additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements may be found under the Item 1A in Cerner's Form 10-K together with the company's other filings. A reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures discussed in the earnings call can be found in the company's earning release, which was furnished to the SEC today and posted on the Investors Section of cerner.com.
At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Marc Naughton, Chief Financial Officer of Cerner Corporation. Sir, please go ahead.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michelle. This is Marc Naughton. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with results, highlights and marketplace observations. And then then
componenttext:
Thank you, Michelle. This is Marc Naughton. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to the call. I'll lead off today with a review of the numbers. Zane Burke, our President, will follow me with results, highlights and marketplace observations. And then then Mike Nill, our Chief Operating Officer, will provide some operational highlights. Now I will turn to our results. 
While solid overall, our results included bookings and revenues slightly below our guidance range and earnings at the low end of our range. Starting with bookings. Our bookings revenue in Q3 was $1.434 billion, which reflects a 10% decrease from the very difficult comparable in Q3 of '15 on bookings were an all-time high and have grown 44% over the prior year. Relative to our guidance, bookings were $16 million below the low end of our range, but Q3 was still our second-highest bookings quarter ever. 
Our revenue backlog ended the quarter at $15.471 billion, which is up 11% from $13.876 billion a year ago. Revenue in the quarter was $1.185 billion, which is up 5% over Q3 of '15, but $15 million below the low end of our guidance range of $1.2 million to $1.275 billion. 
The revenue shortfall was mainly system sales and was a result of lower-than-expected technology resale in software bookings for the quarter. The revenue composition for Q3 was $301 million in system sales, $253 million in support and maintenance, $608 million in services and $22 million in reimbursed travel. 
System sales revenue for the quarter was down 7% compared to Q3 of '15 with technology resale declining 21% and license software declining 12%, partially offset by 10% growth in subscriptions. System sales margin percent increased 150 basis points year-over-year to 69%, reflecting lower technology resale mix as well as lower commissions.
Moving to services. Total services revenue, including professional and managed services, was up 13% compared to Q3 of '15. This is in line with our expectations and continues to reflect good execution by our services organizations. Support and maintenance revenue increased 3% over Q3 of '15, slightly below our expectation of mid-single-digit growth due mostly to lower equipment maintenance revenue related to our lower technology resale.
Looking at revenue by geographic segment. Domestic revenue increased 6% over the year ago quarter to $1.06 billion and non-U.S. Revenue was flat year-over-year at $130 million. 
Moving to gross margin. Gross margin for Q3 was 84.6%, which is up from 83.1% in Q3 of '15 due mostly to the lower mix of technology resale and better services margins versus the year-ago period. Now I will discuss spending, operating margin and net earnings.
For these items, we provide both GAAP and adjusted or non-GAAP results. The adjusted results exclude share-based compensation expense, Health Services acquisition-related amortization, acquisition-related deferred revenue and other acquisition-related adjustments, which are detailed and reconciled to GAAP in our earnings release. Looking at operating spending, our third quarter GAAP operating expenses were $759 million compared to $722 million in the year-ago period. 
Adjusted operating expenses were $713 million, which is up 8% compared to Q3 of '15. This growth was primarily driven by growth in personnel expense related to revenue growth generating associates, which is reflected in the sales and client service expense line that increased 11%. Software development increased 3%. G&A was basically flat and amortization of acquisition-related intangibles was down 30%. This represents only $1 million decline from $3 million to $2 million as this line excludes Health Services acquisition-related amortization and the non-GAAP field. 
Moving to operating margins. Our Q3 GAAP operating margin was 20.4% compared to 19.1% in the year-ago period. Our adjusted operating margin was 24.4% in Q3, which is essentially flat to the year-ago period. This is in line with our previous indication that we expect margin expansion to be limited in 2016, but we do continue to believe we can expand margins 50 plus basis points annually after 2016.
Moving to net earnings and EPS. Our GAAP net earnings in Q3 were $170 million, $0.49 per diluted share. Adjusted net earnings were $203 million and adjusted diluted EPS was $0.59, which is up 9% compared to Q3 of '15.
Q3 tax rate was 30%, which is slightly below our expected rate. The benefit of this was largely offset by a $3.7 million write-off of a venture capital investment that is reflected in the other income line. Now I'd like to preview and expense we expect to incur in Q4. We recently offered a new voluntary separation plan, or BSP, to eligible associates. Similar to our program fiber a lesser, the BSP was made available to us associates to meet the minimum level of combined days of 10-year. The irrevocable acceptance period for most associates electing to participate in the BSP ends in December. 
Based on the number of eligible associates and our estimated participation, we expect the corresponding pretax charge in the fourth quarter of 2016 to be approximately $30 million. Similar to our last VSP, we believe will be able to fill may of the positons by participating associates with existing associates, which should create efficiencies in the future while also creating career growth opportunities for our associates.
This completely voluntary program has a very small impact on our total headcount as a number of eligible associates we expect accept the offer revs and less than 2% of our total associates. Also, they should not be viewed as I lay off or a sign we don't expect to grow. We've grown our headcount by over 2,000 people this year and expect to grow headcount next year as well. Now move to our balance sheet.
We ended Q3 with $837 million of total cash and investments, which is up from $720 million in Q2. We did not repurchase stock during the quarter, which means $100 million still remains available for repurchase and the stock repurchase program authorized in March of this year.
Moving to debt. Our total debt, including capital lease obligations, is $573 million, which is down slightly compared to Q2. Total receivables ended the quarter at $985 million, which is essentially flat to Q2. Our Q3 DSO was 76 days, which is down 9 days from 85 in the year-ago period. 
Operating cash flow for the quarter was $240 million, down from $272 million in Q3 of '15. Year-to-date operating cash flow of $822 million still reflect strong growth over the $594 million of operating cash flows for the first 3 quarters of last year. We also expect strong Q4 cash flow. Q3 capital expenditures were $110 million and capitalized software was $74 million.
Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital purchases and capitalized software development cost, was $56 million for the quarter. This is flat compared to Q2 and down compared to Q3 of '15. You today, free cash flow of $266 million is nearly double $134 million generated in the first 3 quarters of last year. Next year, we continue to expect a decline in capital expenditures, which we expect to drive stronger free cash flow. Now I'll go through guidance.
We expect revenue in Q4 to be between $1.225 billion and $1.3 billion with the mid-point reflecting growth of 7% over Q4 of '15. Our guidance reflect our expectation that system sales will increase sequentially compared to Q3, but still be below our original target for the quarter with a lower expected software and hardware. 
We expect Q4 diluted EPS, adjusted diluted EPS, to be $0.60 to $0.62 per share, which is below our original expectation due to the impact of lower system sales. The mid-point of this range is flat compared to Q4 of '15, but recall, we had a $0.03 tax benefit last year.
Moving to bookings guidance. We expect bookings revenue in Q4 of $1.425 billion to $1.575 billion, and the mid-point reflects 11% growth over Q4 of '15. When added, to year-to-date actuals, the mid-point of our Q4 guidance in place of the following expected full year 2016 results. 
Revenue of $4.8 billion compared to a guidance range of $4.9 billion to $5.0 billion; diluted -- adjusted diluted EPS of $2.31 compared to guidance of $2.30 to $2.40; and bookings of $5.5 billion compared to our stated target of exceeding 2015 bookings of $5.4 billion. 
With comparative guidance we provided a year ago, revenue was the only key metric projected to be below our previously guided range. Recall that I shared at our Investor Day in March, approximately 79% of the $5 billion mid-point of our original revenue guidance was scheduled to come out of backlog that existed at the beginning of 26 and. These means that we expect that about $4 billion a revenue will come from backlog that exited the beginning of the year and the remaining $1 billion will come from current year bookings. So far this year, our conversion of backlog is that almost right our targeted levels, and we expect that to continue where we have missed has been on contra vision of bookings to current your revenue, which is reflected in the lower system sales.
Personally, much more of this miss have been due to hardware and software, which is the main reason we still expect to be at the full year adjusted diluted EPS guidance range. Also, while below our initial range, our 2016 revenue is still expected to be 8% to 9% higher than 2015, which is a very tough comparable as it is 30% over 2014.
Now I'd like to provide initial expectations for 2015 -- 2017. We'll provide more formal guidance after we report Q4 results and finalized our 2017 plan. But based on the initial version of our planned we currently expect, 2017 revenue between $5.2 billion and $5.45 billion, reflecting 11% growth at the mid-point. In 2017, adjusted diluted EPS between $2.50 and $2.70, reflecting 13% growth at the mid-point. Current consensus estimates for both revenue and adjusted diluted EPS are at the high end of these guidance ranges largely reflecting the consensus was formed before our Q3 results and Q4 guidance. With that, I will turn the call over to Zane.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color in our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with bookings. While our Q3 bookings were slightly below our guidance range, it was still the second-highest level of boo
componenttext:
Thanks, Marc. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll provide color in our results and make some marketplace observations. I'll start with bookings. 
While our Q3 bookings were slightly below our guidance range, it was still the second-highest level of bookings in our history, second only to Q3 of 2015. In addition, we expect to return the strong bookings growth in Q4. Looking at mix. 34% of bookings in the quarter were from long-term contracts, reflecting one new ITWorks client and strong managed services bookings. This is in a more normal range for long-term bookings but our year-to-date mix is still lower than normal because of the lower long-term bookings in the first half of the year. Bookings this quarter included several large contracts with 35 contracts over $5 million, including 26 over $10 million. From a new client perspective, 34% of bookings this quarter came from outside our core millennial and soul base. This high level of new business reports our ongoing competitiveness and good market activity. 
Looking ahead, we continue to believe the replacement market will remain active given the high number of hospitals on legacy platforms, some of that are being sunset, while yet others preparing for future regulatory and bowed models that made legacy platforms are not well-equipped battle because we a previous of discuss, the timing of these contracts have proven to be less printable, which I will discuss more in a minute.
First, I'll provide some highlights of the quarter. I'll start with revenue cycle, which continues to be strong contributor to our results. The market remains very focused on clinically driven revenue cycle, which is revving strong sales into our base as well as inclusion in new HR deals. We also had good contribution from RevWorks services in the quarter with an expansion in existing relationship and good contribution from our acute and ambulatory revenue cycle services offerings. Our competitiveness in revenue cycle continues to improve across both acute and ambulatory, and this is reflected in fact, that we have displacement end different competitor so far this year. Looking ahead, we remain optimistic that revenue cycle continued to be strong contributor to our growth. We still have a significant life space on solution penetration and opportunities for our consulting services remain high.
Now I'll shift to population health, where we continue to do very well. Our comprehensive approach to population health remains differentiated in the marketplace. The power of our platform and ability to integrate with EHR work flow remain key differentiators, but also continued to strengthen our competitiveness against the niche competitors we face across different categories such as registries, Enterprise Data Warehouse, analytics and care management. 
We are very pleased with our overall progress in population health. Just 2.5 years after our first HealtheIntent solution went live. We have now sold solutions to over 100 client and the HealtheIntent platform is over 300 data connections from more than 80 unique sources. As we've discussed, the scope with many initial population health contracts was mall because most clients are not at risk for large portions of their populations. But we expect to that ongoing shifts in reimbursement will lead to broader risk assumption, which should lead to adoption a more solutions and more lives being managed on a per member per month model. Addition, we are discovering through these of our solution that system or data will enhance our client fee-for-service models. 
Also, our addressable market for population health goes beyond our traditional EHR clients to include ACO's, health plans, governments and employers. In addition, the opportunity goes beyond module to help the intent platform as their significant market provides higher value services that complement our solution offerings. Mike will provide an example of their we are doing this.
Moving to the ambler Tori market where we have another very good quarter. This quarter again included multiple competitive strong contributions from many -- from an blitzer EHR practice management and business office services. In noteworthy ambulatory when during the quarter was being selected to replace our primary cloud-based competitor for ambulatory EHR and business office services at a large investor own IDN it that we believe is there largest client. We signed for one market in Q3 and anticipate expanding it into other markets in the future. This was 1 of 3 displacements of this competitor in the quarter. 
We also had a good quarter in the small hospital market. Our competitiveness in this market remains strong, and we are having success against all competitors. In Q3, we added a community hospitals with head-to-head wins against 5 different competitors. 
Outside the U.S, our revenue was flat year-over-year. Non-U.S. Revenue represents about 11% of our total revenue. So the flat revenue in the quarter didn't really impact our total results. Despite some current macro headwinds, we do expect the non-U.S. Market to become a more meaningful contributor to our results over the long term given the relatively untapped HR solution and services market. Bills believe there will be a large market for our publishing health platform outside the U.S. Now I'd like to provide some perspective on our results and observations on the marketplace. Despite what was in most ways of solid quarter, we are always this pointed if we don't deliver against that is we established. So I'd like to comment about what they think are some of the elements country bidding to results being somewhat less predictable. 
While our part line has continued to increase of this year, and is it record levels, it appeared with a time of closing opportunities has been more challenging. In the EHR replacement market, there continues to be significant number of replacement opportunities, and we continue to win a majority of them. However, the reduced number of our deadlines tied to regulatory mandates have impacted the client sense of margin C. As I indicated, I believe this is primarily timing issue as deals in our forecasts are changing from a calendar perspective and not be lost. 
We have also have less contribution from our ITWorks and RevWorks businesses this year despite a strong pipeline of opportunities. These opportunities remain, I believe, will see much stronger contributions from these businesses in 2017. 
Overall, I feel good about our ability to grow bookings in 2017 given the pipeline for larger works contracts, ongoing EHR replacement opportunities and an expected continuation of the ramp of contributions population health. And as Marc discuss, our initial view of 2015 reflects good and top and bottom line growth. In summary, our results were slightly below our guidance range for revenue because, I still view our results as solid and strong pipeline in place and we remain position for growth going forward. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mike.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll discuss ITWorks and service collaboration with a large employer in leading health system. We'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client and a strong sales back into our client
componenttext:
Thanks, Zane. Good afternoon, everyone. Today, I'll discuss ITWorks and service collaboration with a large employer in leading health system. We'll start with ITWorks. We had a good quarter with 1 new ITWorks client and a strong sales back into our client base. We new client in the quarter was community Hospital that also has 6 clinics. Like most of our ITWorks line, they added additional solutions to the roadmap as part of their agreement. In this case, they'll be adding critical care, oncology and cardiology solutions. 
In addition, they're adding HealtheIntent population health solutions as well. As Zane mentioned, we've had less ITWorks activity so far this year than expected, but our pipeline remains strong and include some clients that                                                                                       are much  larger  than  any  of  our                                                                                                                                                                                                                        existing   ITWorks  client,   which is why we're are confident about the growth in ITWorks bookings for 2017. The value proposition to our clients remain very appealing, especially in an environment where they had pressure on operating cost, limited access to IT talent and increasing pressures in light of the industry issues related to security.
Now I'd like to discuss a new partnerships between Cerner, large employer in Memorial Hermann. Together, the 3 of us have collaborated to create high performance health network for employers. Employers are looking for strategies to improve quality, cost and experience. Leading health systems are creating and looking to grow their insurance offerings. As this emerging market takes shape, Cerner's investing in new capabilities to address this market opportunity. We think the chance to possibly disrupt and drive revenue is compelling. 
Cerner and Houston based Memorial Hermann had a long history of collaboration and innovation. In addition to broad adoption of Cerner Millennium Solutions, they're an early adopter initial HealtheIntent population health solutions have been certainly adopting more solutions and replacing niche suppliers over the past 3 years. This has contributed to their success of running one of the largest best-performing ACOs in the country. 
Memorial Hermann also has its own health plan build our other best provider network in Houston. Within their plan, they've created their own cost and, fully-insured product for a Fortune 500 employer. Country's member services that we will tightly integrated to the health plans and health system helping members maximize the benefits.
We are also providing the technology for the consumer engagement platform, which brings disparate patient and member portals into an organized consolidated experience. As you know, we have administered our own health plan for the past naked, which is allowed us to reduce the growth in our health care costs will also waiting to a better health experience for our associates.
By leveraging this experience and partner with an innovative world-class provider like Memorial Hermann and large forward thinking employer, we are building an approach to value-based credit care that can be a model for other markets. We believe large health systems are uniquely positioned to play a role in helping please move to our value based care. Be offering performance networks -- high-performance networks comprised of high-quality doctors that can provide plans that help employers than the cost curve while also providing a better overall experience and improving the health of their workforce. We look forward to sharing more about this collaboration as we move through the enrollment in large -- in the launch of this offering and then expand these capabilities to other leading health systems, employers and markets. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to questions.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Garen Sarafian with Citi Research.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Hey, Zane, could you just elaborate a little bit on what you're seeing in the market in some of the delays? Could you just maybe give a couple of examples? And then what gives you guys confidence that it's just sort of getting pushed over to a little but further down the road and not necessarily disappearing? Are they putting anything to their budgets next year that gives them confidence or any other metrics that we could rely on?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Garen, thanks for the question. So in the new business marketplace, I'd say our metrics are at all-time highs. So the activity levels are incredibly good. And in fact, we had a very strong new business quarter overall. So we did very well. We just an
componenttext: Yes, Garen, thanks for the question. So in the new business marketplace, I'd say our metrics are at all-time highs. So the activity levels are incredibly good. And in fact, we had a very strong new business quarter overall. So we did very well. We just anticipated doing slightly better, and there were a couple of opportunities that moved and mostly from just a pure timing perspective. So it's not a question of if they're going to do it, if they win. And without the challenges are without the regulatory elements behind it, the regulatory mandate times behind it, some of those clients are moving a little bit slower than they have in the past. So the budgets are there. The activity is there and we're -- we had a high performance quarter in terms of numbers. We had -- that did not our expectations on what we had anticipated to come through for the quarter. So as we look forward, we see our pipeline of activity and those that are in the pipe is very strong and record levels of activity there. And as those of you who have followed us for a long time know we go through our rigorous process in terms of how we qualify those opportunities, how they run through the -- our forecasting process, and that's helped us to provide good predictability historically around the closing of those -- some of those opportunities. In this case, as I have discussed previously, there are some timing gaps. So the activity remain strong. The ability to accurately predict within the number of week, days it's a row, on how we close of the business was not where we have seen it previously. So does that make sense?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, that's useful. And then as a follow-up maybe for Marc. In setting guidance for 2017, given just more uncertainty and sort of predictability in achieving these results. Is the -- has the methodology and coming up with guidance anymore conservative
componenttext: Yes, no, that's useful. And then as a follow-up maybe for Marc. In setting guidance for 2017, given just more uncertainty and sort of predictability in achieving these results. Is the -- has the methodology and coming up with guidance anymore conservative than in prior years? So for example, what percent of the mid-point of next year's revenue has come from backlog versus prior years? Any other metric for that matter?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Garen. It's -- once again, it's early. What we're providing is our kind of U.S. Now, we don't have the 2017 plan completed. As we go through the process, the process will remain as it's only swimming. We will look at the business. We won't make any a
componenttext:
Yes, Garen. It's -- once again, it's early. What we're providing is our kind of U.S. Now, we don't have the 2017 plan completed. As we go through the process, the process will remain as it's only swimming. We will look at the business. We won't make any assumptions that we're going to grow bookings. We will expect bookings to be relatively flat and mix to be relatively similar. And we will then look at our forecast that goes out fourth quarter to see if that forecast supports those assumptions. We'll do all things we do relative to look at spending and looking at opportunities. I would expect, while I don't have the number today, that a material component similar to what we saw coming in '16, which was in the 80%, 79% range, that we would see that same contribution from backlog as we roll into next year. I don't know what the number exactly is going to be. But I think we're going to have that visibility. Once again, I think it will be a focus on the 20% that we've got to go drive, a lot of which comes through system sales. And that's going to be -- we're going to be focus on relative to our forecasting and our assumptions. 
But my philosophy is we're going to do all the work and then we're going to provide you guidance based on our best work. So we can't really -- as I said, we can't really -- as I said, we can't -- my planning process assumes certain things. one of which is what bookings. I don't expect to have flat bookings. Next year, we're basically guiding today that we're going to be relatively flat for bookings. But I think what -- as we look next year, we will certainly, expect to get back on uptick after coming off a very challenging year with a significant increase in bookings last year exceeding that very tough market. This year, is actually did accomplish meant, but we'd expect to get back on track to growing bookings in a similar pace that we have seen in the past. So once again, my comments on plan is to what we've traditionally always done from a actual expectation of bookings. The business expects to grow our bookings. Especially Zane talked about in 2015, the works businesses or 2016, the works businesses weren't an integral part of a lot of our bookings number. We didn't do a lot of big ITWorks deal. In the pipeline, there are more opportunities in that space. And given that and the size of those bookings, gives us kind of a higher level of confidence that '17 bookings are going to be stronger than '16.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marc, actually, just wanted to follow up on that until those bookings comments. Just to be clear, is in the 2017 preliminary revenue outlook that you're providing tonight, is that assume no bookings growth? And then I guess just as I think about the short
componenttext: Marc, actually, just wanted to follow up on that until those bookings comments. Just to be clear, is in the 2017 preliminary revenue outlook that you're providing tonight, is that assume no bookings growth? And then I guess just as I think about the short-term bookings, it does look like you're calling for a pickup in 4Q. I'm just curious, as you look out into next year, is this just a conservative assumption to assume? You don't see bookings growth? Or are you actually baking in some as you think about 2017?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and let me be very clear. We expect bookings to grow in 2017. That is our expectation. The business is there. Everything were seeing  in our forecasting process, which close out 4 quarters. So we actually have a view out that long as the what's the o
componenttext:
Yes, and let me be very clear. We expect bookings to grow in 2017. That is our expectation. The business is there. Everything were seeing  in our forecasting process, which close out 4 quarters. So we actually have a view out that long as the what's the opportunities our. And as Zane said, it's at record levels. So we see bookings growing next year. My point is relative to us doing a plan, the question kind of came at is their level of conservatism? And for us, we don't expect -- we don't plan the bookings are going to grow. We expect them to grow. But by not building that into the plan, that gives us some degree of cushion should they not grow to deliver the numbers that we provided in our guidance. And so I think that's our expectation. Expect bookings the group it was a and expect bookings to grow. The opportunities are there. So we will see higher bookings in '17. But relative to giving you guidance, especially preliminary guidance, we're not going to go build growth in bookings into those preliminary numbers. 
When we come back to you after Q4 ends with a completely built backlog and has our best view, then we'll certainly tie down those numbers. But at this point, based on our normal process, which was done every year, we're comfortable with the guidance we're providing relative to a first look at '17 and once again, realizing we got to get to our planning process to tie down.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's fair. I guess, just one more specific follow-up around that. If I think about '16 and maybe one of the things that was disappointing relative to your expectations coming into the year probably will be around the works pipeline. It seems like th
componenttext: No, that's fair. I guess, just one more specific follow-up around that. If I think about '16 and maybe one of the things that was disappointing relative to your expectations coming into the year probably will be around the works pipeline. It seems like the expectations for some of these large work deals to be implemented is obviously moved throughout the year. I guess, the question is, what changes in '17 as far as the systems that you've been talking to around 18 -- ITWorks and RevWorks. What changes that you see them actually moving forward with those contracts?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robert, this is Zane. I think what we're seeing is move -- some of those things moving through the pipeline a little bit faster in terms of -- not faster, but just maturing more appropriately through there. And so what's really going on is when you make t
componenttext: Robert, this is Zane. I think what we're seeing is move -- some of those things moving through the pipeline a little bit faster in terms of -- not faster, but just maturing more appropriately through there. And so what's really going on is when you make this move, it's a combination of things. So there's always a how to grow faster. And so when you look at MACRA and MIPS, our clients are going to have a need to be able to measure and monitor a number of different metrics to beginning to prepare for that. And when they look at what the pressure there under front for MACRA, MIPS, those kind of things are going to drive additional behavior around ITWorks in addition to decreasing reimbursement environment creates a costs strain at a time when they need access to more data. They need more IT to actually be able to answer all these questions. So the combination of the -- those regulatory elements at a capital and operating constrained environment at a point in time whether trying to just flat out execute what we offer for our clients is provide that kind of leverage. And I think what we saw in '16 is there was almost a catch your breadth mentality in that we did not have any of those major elements around Meaningful Use. In the current year, we didn't have the MACRA MIPS, and in addition, the bottom lines for our clients were still pretty strong. What you're seeing, as you go to the back half of the year, is a little bit of weakness with the bottom line, and that regulatory environment is coming on. That's actually a really big positive for the IT -- for the works programs themselves. But revenue cycle and ITWorks. And so in the conversations that we're having, they're continuing along. And I feel like those are going to mature in a good way in '17 that we just didn't see in '16 with that kind of catch your breadth element in some of those areas.

componenttext: Thanks for the question. So from a VA perspective, I think with the administrations changing and some of those elements that there is -- I don't think that's an expectation that that's going to be in the immediate horizon. But there is clearly a dialogue and has been from them around making a change out of this -- in the long run local and should we be called upon that -- to respond to that and get asked, I would be excited to perform. I think our best model is to continue to perform on the DoD, which we are performing very well on, and the follow-on opportunities for that are quite significant in and off themselves. So as you think about '17 and '18 and the future, we have a unique position both firm the DOD perspective. Obviously, the additional opportunities that are not yet book as part of that opportunity but also to set us up to be in good position to think about competing well around of the the a. And so our model is put our head down, be very successful with the DOD. That will yield a lot of positive results for 2017 in terms of system sales for Sunder Corporation that are unique to Cerner as well as positions for the VA.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: David, we've said the bookings from DOD tend to be kind of steady and not significant in any one quarter. They weren't significant. But it isn't -- it was so material, then we're going to -- then we talked about it. But it spreads out through multiple periods. componenttext: Sure, have a tell put some of those things but there are some of those things that we do not provide numbers around. But it's proprietary for us. What I will say in terms absolute dollars across all segments, our pipeline is the highest level in history of the company. So that's kind of the ultimate metric in terms of what we are looking for. That's after we took the second highest level of bookings in the history of the company out of the pipeline. So I think that's an important element to think of first when you're thinking about the health of where we are provides for a certain areas of strength in the marketplace, certainly, you look at community hospitals. That's very strong marketplace for us. The small hospital marketplace is very strong. Some places where we uniquely compete around the investor-owned segment, around the government both from a federal and a state and local perspective. Those are pretty -- those are very active parts of the marketplace, as well as our population health solution set. So there are just a number of areas that we are very strong and continue to be very active.

componenttext: Well, I think you can just, even looking at the last 2 quarters, there's $150 million that's, out of our revenue guidance. So that's going to impact basically, take you down the $150 million, I just in the last half of the year. So I think that's -- less of a material amount always been we are giving guidance. We were looking for a pretty significant uptake as we went through. And if you look at our Q4 guidance, I mean, we're looking at a $78 million uptick at the mid-point of our revenue guidance range. componenttext: Yes, I think the other thing I would add is that the big difference, as Marc discussed, first low-margin tech result and frankly, low-margin ITWorks bookings that we would have anticipated would have been in the numbers. componenttext: Thanks, Marc. The -- around the international marketplaces, there are a few markets that feel very positive as we look at it. There are some who are investing more and help charity, like Belgium, like Sweden and you see that like Australia. And then, there's some interesting ones where you look at as the country like the U.K, which is under incredible cost pressure. And that pressure really forces the change. It forces the need for no more IT, frankly. And we were -- you maybe aware we were awarded 6 of our 13 -- or clients were awarded 6 of the 13 clients grand around innovation. So GBP 10 billion innovation bounce by, which she they are charged with figuring out ways to use IT to lower cost and improve efficiencies in the U.K. And so I look at a couple of markets where there's recognition for -- they're doing well economically and they want to go invest in health care structures, like Belgium, like Sweden, or they're struggling and it's going to force of the change, like the U.K. And I think we're well positioned in those marketplace to have some good success. I also think Canada has the opportunity in 2017 and 2018 to be a very strong marketplace as they look at some more eventually wide procurements. And those tend to take time and are very, very challenging in which to predict how those will come to closure. But there's -- I feel very good about how we're positioned in many of those strong marketplaces.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I want to be clear. It's not -- all of these organizations are making a decision they need to change. And so the delays don't have anything to do with -- from a solution perspective or anything like that. It is truly a process and a need to -- these are significant purchases for these hospitals. It's literally a do I want to buy a new EHR, which they know they have to compete for the future? Or am I going to go and invest in some sort of the other pieces? On the existing client, the ROI around some of the connectivity pieces to other parts of the business, whether that's device, connectivity. Whether that's their ambulatory marketplace, whether its efficiencies. There is of focus on a return on investments, which breaks through the pause, if you will, or kind of the breathing Messiah of breathing for 2016. Those kind of projects gain traction in this environment we were competing for capital. So it's kind of the heart ROI element. Our staff schedule, our staff acuity solutions sets, having a clinically integrated revenue cycle has been a very strong element. Again, it's bringing things together. Same things that drive actually the new marketplace. How do I go round out my solution set such that I have a fully integrated solution capability and I've got data liquidity across my enterprise. And ROI doesn't hurt anything in terms of getting it moving forward. So thanks for the question.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- clearly, license software or subscription is just 2 ways of selling intangible and the delectable property, right? So from our view, Q3 was a little bit of a unique circumstance in that, Zane talked about, there was a lot of business
componenttext:
Well, I think the -- clearly, license software or subscription is just 2 ways of selling intangible and the delectable property, right? So from our view, Q3 was a little bit of a unique circumstance in that, Zane talked about, there was a lot of business in the quarter and a lot of software opportunities that because of -- the timing issues that we're seeing didn't get down in Q3. We see that rebounded in Q4, expect to get back kind of to more traditional levels. The reason I always talked about softer before is that it really hasn't been different enough to highlight, the tech resales has been different enough that it's been a cause of a difference. So that's one reasons. The variance between subscription and license, it really just Benson how we're selling it and how the clients buy it. We will -- as we go-to-market, we'll go-to-market in a right-of-ways. They want to buy the software, want to buy has a time, term license that's more of a subscription. If they want on the health side, a lot of it much of with this month per member per month. So much more of like a ASP or subscription basis. So I don't know that, that mix is relevant to our business as a Q3 for some of those opportunities because some of them -- size have look to a different period. But I think overall, we're a software company, we expect that to rebound. Our pipeline is strong, and we have the opportunity to go sell software. People are still buying softer in this marketplace. So I think the -- our opportunities. And then we just got to get to the point where we can -- and we are at that point where we can effectively deliver on a fixed fee basis. The technology they need, Zane made a really good point earlier about MACRA and the impact of that has a just a general desire for technology.
Thing, I see stock and other existing client base, what they're needing. Some of that is going to be driven by their desire to have all of the data that's going to be required under MACRA make sure that they have a single line of proof to go get abated in be able to go get the data they need. Yes, I don't know how we sell it image months more different. We still solved, sell it. Q3, I think, was a low number. We've highlighted it because that's we want to be transparent. Q4, we don't think that's going to be an issue.

componenttext: Well, obviously, we continue to spend a significant amount of our R&D on new items that capitalize an event goal great some feature points. We talked coming to this year that we expected to have noncash expenses on some of the amortization on that, hitting this in 2016, has hit us, it didn't -- has not hit us as much as we had originally expected. So I think you will see some carryover impact on the '17 R&D expenses as that amortization starts ramps up early next year. We continue to deliver the code. We're doing it on an tamely basis. In some cases, we get to Jaime require testing by our client partners. And sometimes that time and gets -- is not exactly within our schedule that we would do amortization. So I think you'll see next year similar level of capitalization because we are still working on new stuff. The overall expense will take a slightly from the amortization element of being slightly higher for the mall that bit in get it into the number this year. So R&D expense basically is likely, as we look at it, goes up a little bit as we head into 2017, but not significant adjustments. But once again, what we didn't see in '16 will come to crews in '17.

componenttext: This is a follow-up. When you think about the gross R&D spend, I mean, I know when you guys an ounce of the Siemens transaction, one of the major bullet points was the amount of kind of combined R&D spend between the 2 organizations and the likelihood that there wouldn't need to be a significant growth for number of years in Canada that gross R&D spend. componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think that's definitely part of our plan. You're going to -- the goal was around the $700 million, so that should be enough to grow deliver on what we're trying to do. It's very worse. Any growth changes should be kind of low single-digit. So d
componenttext: Yes. No, I think that's definitely part of our plan. You're going to -- the goal was around the $700 million, so that should be enough to grow deliver on what we're trying to do. It's very worse. Any growth changes should be kind of low single-digit. So definitely, growing at our rate lower than our revenue is growing. But I think, long-term, if you just looking at the end of ordinary increases, kind of mid-single-digit growth, we'll be something that will be along lines our expectation. We are -- we still have opportunities. We are still using some of the acquired resources to work and get to a point on some of the HS solutions. And so those people will become available capacity roll forward. And we are investing heavily in our India campuses. So our expectation there. We will be bringing online more IP resources in that environment, which from a headcount perspective, we'll increase, but from a cost perspective, we'll fit in with that single, mid single-digit future growth.

componenttext: So a couple of questions here. So first of all, when we look at the contract just to rewrite it. It seems that this quarter, the percent of contrast from are long-term in nature. It's the highest it's been since Q2. So should we think about this as a leading indicator for just again, a step down in booking conversion in 2017? But it seems that, that size of contract, the bigger the contract is, seems to be's more complicated when therefore, slower to convert. That's question one. And then second of all, if you can give us some sense of booking growth, what percent came from pop health and what percent from this big international contracts you've talked about?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just address the bookings. I think the comment kind of revolves around the long-term element of the bookings. Keep in mind that if you look at year-to-date, in 2015, long-term bookings were 34% of our total bookings. If you look at this year, it's
componenttext: Let me just address the bookings. I think the comment kind of revolves around the long-term element of the bookings. Keep in mind that if you look at year-to-date, in 2015, long-term bookings were 34% of our total bookings. If you look at this year, it's been about 29% because actually, for us to be relatively flat or and we're looking to be slightly up over a year, we are actively not getting the support from the long-term bookings, which we talked about from the work deals. I think that's actually a point that should go unnoticed. But I think from -- welcome to the overall contracts, every contract has some degree of these aren't simple, but they aren't -- they're not rocket science, right? They want to buy stuff. We want to sell stuff. There's a lot of parameters are on that. But we have a lot of the space but we also talk but the contract together. So I do think the complexity of contracts is delaying the timing of the contracts. I think the delay -- I think that is just more a matter of the organization's timing and focus and strategic planning and they don't have an outside regulatory timeline they have to go meet for some of these things. MACRA could change that. MACRA may make them do more -- be more focused on making sure they have the solutions throughout all of their departments so that they can get day-to-day daily to do that reporting. But I think that -- so I think the complexity has been somewhat complex. It's just a matter of the timing of the client. To do that, the money is there. As Zane says within our pipeline, it's just time down the 90-day period at which is going to actually sign is a little limit more traditional to what it was prior to having Meaningful Use in all of those regulatory things have occurred.

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And then on the booking growth and from pop health, what percent of pop health and what percent of international?

headline: Cerner Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pop health is a very little piece of bookings growth at this point. I mean, we have some -- today, we be by let version of pop health, $5 million bookings is a good site publish and bookings. 'S if not, need or $1 billion bookings number. And relative to
componenttext:
Pop health is a very little piece of bookings growth at this point. I mean, we have some -- today, we be by let version of pop health, $5 million bookings is a good site publish and bookings. 'S if not, need or $1 billion bookings number. And relative to global, those bookings have been basically relatively flat, if not, a little bit lower. Over the last year, Zane said, there's some opportunities going forward especially in Canada in some other countries that look like demand is beginning to pick up. So we think that will help the global side. But most of the bookings and most of the stuff growth you're seeing is not pop health, not international, it is our core, core businesses that we've always been in.
Well, I want to thank everybody for their time. I think we're still on pace to grow bookings and revenue this year over a very tough comp. And I think we're all absolutely on path to grow revenue and earnings double-digit in 2017. 
So I think based on our pipeline, based on the ITWorks opportunities we have, we do continue to expect to grow bookings year-over-year in 2017. 
With that, I will thank you for your attendance and bid you good day.
